document.title: Current learning in palliative care index
document.topics: <![CDATA[ END-OF-LIFE CARE,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.description: 15 minute tutorials on various aspects of palliative care
document.body:
Extract from website

Helping others to learn about caring for people with advanced disease has always been a fundamental part of effective palliative care.  The aim is to resource existing professionals, carers and teams with the knowledge and skills needed in their daily work.

The CLIP worksheets grew from the idea of a "coffee update".  The principle was to develop a flexible learning material that could be used over a coffee break, but could also be used in a variety of settings.

All the CLIP worksheets have been adapted as online tutorials, with permission, by Help the Hospices from Helping the Patient with Advanced Disease: a Workbook by Regnard C, ed. Radcliffe Medical Press 2004.

Published in 2006

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Kidney Diseases and Male Urogenital Disorders]]>
document.title: Cystic Diseases of the Kidney
document.topics: <![CDATA[ INHERITED KIDNEY DISEASE,POLYCYSTIC KIDNEY DISEASE,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.description: Information from eMedicine.com
document.body:
Extract from website

 Renal cysts occur in one third of people older than 50 years. While most are simple cysts, renal cystic disease has multiple etiologies. Broad categories of cystic disease include the following:

  • Congenital - Congenital cystic dysplasia

  • Genetic - Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD), autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD), nephronophthisis-medullary cystic kidney disease complex (NMCD)

  • Acquired - Simple cysts, acquired cystic disease

  • Cysts associated with systemic disease - Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome (VHLS), tuberous sclerosis (TS)

  • Malignancy - Renal cell carcinoma (RCC)

The most common larger cysts are acquired cysts, simple cysts, and cysts with ADPKD. Smaller cysts are associated with ARPKD, NMCD, and medullary sponge kidney (MSK). In adults, renal angiomyolipomas and RCC also may demonstrate cystic lesions.

 

]]>

document.body:
111-1December 2009 NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders newsletter

Welcome to the kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders specialist collection enewsletter for December 2009.

 

NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders is for busy health professionals, providing them with high quality information and keeping them up to date with the latest research and developments in this area. You can now join our mailing list to receive regular updates. Click here for the link.

 

 

****2009 Annual Evidence Update on Post Transplant Lymphoproliferative Disorders in Renal Transplant patients 7-11 December 2009. ****

This Annual Evidence Update is being launched on Monday 7th December 2009 to link to and raise awareness of the Guidelines on the surveillance, diagnosis and management of post transplant lymphoproliferative disorders in adult solid organ transplant recipients, recently published by the British Transplant Society.

Click here for the contents page

 

Links to:

  • New Kidney Diseases items
  • New Male Urogenital Disorders items

 

 RSS FEEDS 

 

You can receive news from the kidney diseases specialist collection from the RSS feeds we provide:

  1.  New Kidney Diseases Resources
  2.  New Male Urogenital Disorders Resources
  3.  Kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders in the news

Click through this link to find out more about RSS feeds.

 

JOURNALS

You can link through to the latest Tables of Contents from all the major kidney, transplant and urology journals from this page.

 

New resources added in November 2009

 

Chronic Kidney  Disease

  • Does epoetin alfa improve health-related quality of life in chronically ill patients with anemia: summary of trials of cancer, HIV/AIDS, and chronic kidney disease. Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects (DARE) abstract.
  • Effectiveness and efficiency of primary care based case management for chronic diseases: systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized and non-randomized trials. (Protocol for a systematic review). CRD Health Technology Assessment Database (HTA) abstract and links.
  • IV placement in chronic kidney disease patients. HTA abstract and links.
  • Renal replacement therapy in advanced chronic kidney disease. HTA abstract and links.
  • NICE guideline on Depression in adults with a chronic physical health problem: treatment and management.
  • BNF advice on dose adjustment in renal impairment now expressed in terms of eGFR rather than creatinine clearance. Analysis by the National electronic Library for Medicines (19/11/09)
  • So Just What Can I Eat? Nutritional Care in Patients with Diabetes Mellitus and Chronic Kidney Disease. Nephrology Nursing Journal article.
  • Achieving Autonomy for Kidney Services: Seven Steps Toolkit 2009. Service guidance from NHS Kidney Care.

Acute kidney injury

  • N-acetylcysteine to reduce renal failure after cardiac surgery: a systematic review and meta-analysis. DARE abstract.

Renovascular disease

  • Treatment to open blocked kidney arteries shows no real benefit. Kidney Research UK news item: 

End stage renal disease

  • Intradialytic parenteral nutrition (IDPN) for end-stage renal disease in adults. HTA abstract and links.

Diabetic nephropathy

  • Commentary on Diabetic Nephropathy for the 2009 Diabetes Annual Evidence Update. This editorial has been written by Dr Edward Sharples for the diabetes specialist collection. 

Dialysis

  • Review of the starting criteria in dialysis programs and assessment of the efficacy and effectiveness of an early start. HTA abstract and links.
  • NHS Choices video on home haemodialysis.
  • NHS Choices video on dialysis

Transplantation

  • Estimated benefits of transplantation of kidneys from donors at increased risk for HIV or hepatitis C infection. NHS Economic Evaluation Database (NEED) abstract.
  • Selective IgG Apheresis for ABO-incompatible kidney transplantation. Systematic Review. HTA abstract.
  • KDIGO Clinical Practice Guideline for the Care of Kidney Transplant Recipients.
  • Legal issues relevant to non-heartbeating organ donation. Department of Health.
  • Organ transplants using 'risky donors' rising. Link to BBC news item
  • Call to put organ donor register in polling stations. Link to BBC news item
  • Organ transplants' hidden risk. Link to BBC news item.

Kidney Cancer

  • Sunitinib for the management of renal cell carcinoma. HTA abstract. 
  • Sunitinib in metastatic renal-cell cancer: efficacy and safety. HTA abstract. 
  • NHS Evidence – cancer: Two systematic reviews on kidney cancer and surgery as treatment management highlighted.

 

Male Urogenital Disorders

  • Green light laser urological indications. HTA abstract.
  • One for the lads, or lavs? Link to Guardian news item. 

Male Bladder Disorders

  • The effectiveness of nurse led 2-D ultrasound guided insertion of peripherally inserted central catheters in adult patients: a systematic review. DARE abstract.
  • Biopatch antimicrobial dressing (Integra LifeSciences Corp. and Ethicon Inc., a division of Johnson & Johnson Co.) for prevention of catheter- and device-related bloodstream infections. HTA abstract.
  • Doctors' warning on ketamine risk. Link to BBC news item.
  • Systematic review on surgery for bladder cancer. NHS Evidence – cancer.

Prostate Disorders

  • Adjuvant radiotherapy following radical prostatectomy for pathologic T3 or margin-positive prostate cancer: guideline recommendations. DARE abstract.
  • 3.0 Tesla (3T) Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) for Prostate Cancer. HTA abstract
  • High-intensity focused ultrasound for prostate cancer [Le traitement du cancer de la prostate par ultrasons focalises de haute intensite - in French only] HTA abstract
  • Intensity modulated radiotherapy (IMRT) for prostate cancer. HTA abstract
  • Non-drug local procedures in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia. HTA abstract
  • Photoselective vaporization for benign prostatic hyperplasia with KTP (potassium-titanyl-phosphate) laser or GreenLight. HTA abstract
  • Robot Assisted Radical Prostatectomy (RARP) [Prostatectomie radicale assistee par robot - in French only] (project). HTA abstract
  • Robot-assisted surgery in prostate cancer. HTA abstract
  • Systematic review and economic modelling of effectiveness and cost utility of surgical treatments for men with benign prostatic enlargement. HTA abstract
  • Use of classical and novel biomarkers as prognostic risk factors for localised prostate cancer: a systematic review. HTA abstract
  • Usefulness of high-intensity focused ultrasound in prostate cancer. HTA abstract
  • Darcus Howe: My battle with prostate cancer. Link to Guardian article
  • Literature review on psychosocial care for prostate cancer. NHS Evidence – cancer.
  • Systematic review on Biological therapy for prostate cancer. NHS Evidence – cancer.

Penile Disorders

  • Oral phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors and hormonal treatments for erectile dysfunction: a systematic review and meta-analysis. DARE abstract.
  • Rapid Review - Non-therapeutic male circumcision. Report No. 65. HTA abstract.
  • Penis tissue replaced in the lab. Link to BBC news item.

Male Urethral Disorders

  • Dipsticks and diagnostic algorithms in urinary tract infection: development and validation, randomised trial, economic analysis, observational cohort, and qualitative study. HTA abstract.
  • Evaluation of home care utility: pneumonia, cerebrovascular disease, urinary tract infections and postsurgical infections.  HTA abstract.
  • Health Protection Agency care guideline on Diagnosis of UTI: quick reference guide for primary care.

Testicular/Scrotal Disorders

  • Systematic review on testicular cancer and diagnostic imaging. NHS Evidence – cancer.
  • Testicular cancer: Treatment and Disease management: Surgery. Systematic review added by NHS Evidence – cancer team.

Male urinary incontinence

  • Treatment interventions in nursing home residents with urinary incontinence: a systematic review of randomized trials. DARE abstract.
  • New minimally invasive methods in the treatment of stress urinary incontinence. Systematic review. HTA abstract and links.
  • Retroluminal transobturatoric reposition sling for the treatment of stress urinary incontinence in men. Systematic Review. HTA abstract and links.

Sexually Transmitted Infections

  • The impact of HIV treatment on risk behaviour in developing countries: a systematic review. DARE abstract.
  • Non-occupational post-exposure prophylaxis for HIV: a systematic review. HTA abstract and links.

Fertility

  • Do sperm DNA integrity tests predict pregnancy with in vitro fertilization? DARE abstract.

 

**Subscribe to the NHS Evidence Eyes on Evidence Newsletter**


If you would like to receive Eyes on Evidence, the monthly e-bulletin from NHS Evidence, please sign up at http://www.evidence.nhs.uk/NewsletterSignup.aspx.


The bulletin will keep you updated with new and important evidence and key developments on the NHS Evidence portal.  It comes out on the second Wednesday of the month and can be sent to any e-mail address that you provide.

]]>

  • Dialysis- Systematic reviews and meta-analyses. New systematic reviews identified by the specialist collection team have been added to this page.
  • RCT - In-Center Hemodialysis Six Times per Week versus Three Times per Week. The FHN Trial Group. Published 20/11/10 in the NEJM. Link to abstract
  • Improving medication safety in chronic kidney disease patients on dialysis through medication reconciliation. National electronic Library for Medicines (16/11/10).


Peritoneal Dialysis
 

  • Peritoneal dialysis- Systematic reviews and meta-analyses. New systematic reviews identified by the specialist collection team have been added to this page.

Transplantation

  • Renal Tsar Q and A - Transplant chances. Published 01/11/10 by Dr Donal O'Donoghue.
  • Renal transplant- Systematic reviews and meta-analyses. New systematic reviews identified by the specialist collection team have been added to this page.
  • Living kidney donors- Systematic reviews and meta-analyses. New systematic reviews identified by the specialist collection team have been added to this page.
  • Nephrectomy- Systematic reviews and meta-analyses. New systematic reviews identified by the specialist collection team have been added to this page.

Kidney Cancer

  • Cost-effectiveness of temsirolimus for first line treatment of advanced renal cell carcinoma. A new record from the CRD NHS Economic Evaluation Database.
  • Cost-effectiveness of sorafenib for second-line treatment of advanced renal cell carcinoma. A new record from the CRD NHS Economic Evaluation Database.

 

Male Urogenital Disorders

 

Male Ureteric Disorders

  • Vesico-ureter-reflux- Systematic reviews and meta-analyses. New systematic reviews identified by the specialist collection team have been added to this page.

Male Bladder Disorders

  • Kidney and bladder stones- Systematic reviews and meta-analyses. New systematic reviews identified by the specialist collection team have been added to this page.
  • Male bladder disorders- Systematic reviews and meta-analyses. New systematic reviews identified by the specialist collection team have been added to this page.
  • Bladder cancer surveillance UPDATE. A new record from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Screening adults for bladder cancer- update of the 2004 evidence review for the US Preventive Services Task Force. A new record from the CRD Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.
  • New content - systematic reviews and meta analyses on overactive bladder. The specialist collection team have retrieved the high-level evidence on overactive bladder published 2006 - 2010.

Prostate Disorders

  • Improvement in the quality of information on colorectal and prostate cancer in the cancer population register of the Basque Country. A new record from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Survival in men with nonmetastatic prostate cancer treated with hormone therapy- a quantitative systematic review. A new record from the CRD Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.
  • Higher-than-conventional radiation doses in localized prostate cancer treatment- a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials. A new record from the CRD Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.
  • Efficacy and safety of tamsulosin for the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia- a meta analysis. A new record from the CRD Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.
  • Radical prostatectomy versus watchful waiting for prostate cancer. A new Cochrane systematic review.
  • Reimbursement policy and androgen-deprivation therapy for prostate cancer. National electronic Library for Medicines (05/11/10).
  • Impact of androgen deprivation therapy on physical and cognitive function and quality of life in men with non-metastatic prostate cancer. National electronic Library for Medicines (04/11/10). 
  • Zibotentan for metastatic castration resistant prostate cancer - first line. A new record from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database. 
  • Sipuleucel-T for hormone-resistant metastatic prostate cancer. A new record from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Prostate cancer screening. A new record from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database. 
     

Penile Disorders

  • No new resources this month.

Urethral disorders

  • No new resources this month.

Urinary tract infections

  • Cost effectiveness of management strategies for urinary tract infections- results from randomised controlled trial. A new record from the CRD NHS Economic Evaluation Database

Testicular/Scrotal Disorders

  • No new resources this month.

Male Urinary Incontinence

  • New NICE Bites topic on Nocturnal Enuresis.

Sexually Transmitted Infections

  • No new resources this month.

Fertility

  • Sperm DNA fragmentation and annexin column use in assisted reproductive treatments. A new record from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.

 

]]>

document.body:
111-1Diabetic Nephropathy: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses

NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders has identified the following resources relevant to this topic area. We perform systematic searches to identify up-to-date, high quality evidence for a given topic. View our content development strategy for more information.

Users should note that we have not performed an in-depth appraisal for each reference but have applied rigorous methods to select them.  Where pre-appraisals exist, we link to them.   We recommend that a full appraisal is completed using the appropriate check-list provided by the Centre for Evidence-Based Medicine.  We welcome feedback about resources that we identify, do contact us if you would like to comment.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Kidney Diseases and Male Urogenital Disorders]]>
document.title: Dialysis Capacity Survey
document.topics: <![CDATA[ KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY DISEASES,DIALYSIS]]>
document.description: This project aims to capture the national profile of dialysis services across England, to help ensure that kidney services can be prioritised at a national level.
document.body:
What does this project aim to achieve?

This project aims to capture the national profile of dialysis services across England, to help ensure that kidney services can be prioritised at a national level.
 
How is this being achieved?

NHS Kidney Care is working with local kidney care networks to gather information about kidney services in England. A spreadsheet (Excel 29KB) has been developed in collaboration with the Renal Association, which will capture the current provision of service, as well as the capacity available nationally. It requests information about current patients and capacity (at 30 September 2009), as well as plans for expansion between 2009/10 and 2014/15. Each local network has been asked to complete the spreadsheet, so that a national profile can be compiled.

 

The national profile is expected to be complete in Spring 2010.


 
What are the key deliverables?

Once the national profile has been developed, it will be shared with all renal clinical directors in England, for use in discussions with local commissioners.


Dialysis Capacity Survey Results


Download the results from the first Dialysis Capacity Survey (Link to full-text PDF)

]]>

document.title: Diet, nutrition and kidney diseases: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders
document.topics: <![CDATA[ INTERVENTIONS,DIETARY CHANGE,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.body:
111-1Diet, nutrition and kidney diseases: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses

NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders has identified the following resources relevant to this topic area. We perform systematic searches to identify up-to-date, high quality evidence for a given topic. View our content development strategy for more information.

Users should note that we have not performed an in-depth appraisal for each reference but have applied rigorous methods to select them.  Where pre-appraisals exist, we link to them.   We recommend that a full appraisal is completed using the appropriate check-list provided by the Centre for Evidence-Based Medicine.  We welcome feedback about resources that we identify, do contact us if you would like to comment.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Kidney Diseases and Male Urogenital Disorders]]>
document.title: Discontinuing treatment: key issues and ethical dilemmas
document.topics: <![CDATA[ END-OF-LIFE CARE,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.description: Article about developing renal palliative care services, and taking forward the NSF end of life module.
document.body:
Extract from website

Stopping dialysis presents health care professionals with both a unique opportunity and an important challenge in the care of their patients. Between 12 and 18% of patients may choose to stop dialysis as the burden of symptoms from co-morbidity, the presence of other life threatening illness or the burden of dialysis comes to outweigh its benefits. Key areas for consideration at this time include:

  1. Effective communication both between health care professionals and the patient and family and also between professionals themselves
  2. Making sure reversible factors are excluded
  3. The use of advance directives
  4. Ensuring that patients have capacity to make decisions
  5. The involvement and support to family or other carers as the decision is made.

 

]]>

document.title: Driving Service Improvement through Patient Focus
document.topics: <![CDATA[ NATIONAL SERVICE FRAMEWORK FOR RENAL SERVICES/POLICY DOCUMENTS,ACUTE KIDNEY INJURY,KIDNEY DISEASE IN CHILDREN AND ADOLESCENTS,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.description: Report of the Phase II Renal Action Learning Sets 2006-2007 and supporting information
document.body:
Extract

Following the success of the first renal action learning sets, the Department of Health commissioned a second phase of this programme comprising six sets which ran from October 2006 to October 2007. These sets focussed on three areas of service improvement using action learning: the pre-dialysis year; transition from paediatric to adult services and acute renal failure. The final report covers the methods used by the sets, and the learning that they gained over the year. It is supported by a pack of detailed supporting information.

 

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ PREDISPOSING FACTORS,SCREENING OPTIONS,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.description: Second National Symposium, British Library June 2004
document.body:
Symposium covering main concerns of south asian communities with regard to early detection of renal failure.

The Symposium was divided into 3 sessions - Identifying the problem, Experiencing the problem, and Solving the problem.

Identifying the problem- Opening speech, epidemiology of renal failure, managing cardiovascular risk in CKD, Managing Diabetes and Renal Disease

Experiencing the problem - Expert patient experience of renal diagnosis and referral, GPs and renal medicine, challenges of collaborative relationship, benefits of early referral in treatment, identification of CKD- the NeoErica Project

Solving the problem - renal guidelines for primary care 

]]>

document.title: Eat right to feel right on hemodialysis
document.publisher: National Kidney and Urologic Diseases Information Clearinghouse (NKUDIC)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ INTERVENTIONS,DIETARY CHANGE,STARTING HAEMODIALYSIS,STARTING PERITONEAL DIALYSIS,LIVING WITH DIALYSIS,HAEMODIALYSIS,PERITONEAL DIALYSIS,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE,DIALYSIS,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.description: Website providing information on diet whilst on hemodialysis
document.body:
Extract from website

How to Use This Publication

When you start hemodialysis, you must make many changes in your life. Watching the foods you eat will make you healthier. This publication will help you choose the right foods.

Print this publication and use it with a dietitian to help you learn how to eat right to feel right on hemodialysis. Read one section at a time. Then go through the exercise with your dietitian.

Once you have completed every exercise, keep a copy of this publication to remind yourself of foods you can eat and foods you need to avoid.

Published December 2006

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Kidney Diseases and Male Urogenital Disorders]]>
document.title: eGFR resources page - Information to support eGFR reporting
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SCREENING OPTIONS,SCREENING TESTS,ASSESSMENT TESTS,ASSESSMENT OF RENAL FUNCTION,GFR AND EGFR,EGFR,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.description: Web page of links from the Renal Association
document.body:
Extract from webpage

eGFR (estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate) reporting is seen as a key element in achieving earlier detection of serious CKD, and early institution of preventive measures. The UK CKD guidelines (2005) and many other guidelines internationally support the general introduction of eGFR reporting.

Introduction of eGFR reporting is likely to lead to many extra patients being identified as having CKD, especially in older age groups. It is widely agreed that it both unfeasible and unnecessary that all of these should be referred to nephrologists. The UK CKD guidelines support the management of most patients with moderate GFR reduction (down to 30mls/min/1.73m2 if stable, and with low levels of urinary protein/blood) in the community.

This page accommodates discussions and links to a large number of resources to support the introduction of eGFR reporting in the UK.

 

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Kidney Diseases and Male Urogenital Disorders]]>
document.title: Electronic consultation as an alternative to hospital referral for patients with chronic kidney disease: a novel application for networked electronic health records to improve the accessibility and efficiency of healthcare.
document.publisher: Quality and Safety in Health Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLICATIONS OF KIDNEY DISEASE,CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.description: Stoves J, Connolly J, Cheung CK, Grange A, Rhodes P, O'Donoghue D, Wright J. Electronic consultation as an alternative to hospital referral for patients with chronic kidney disease: a novel application for networked electronic health records to improve the accessibility and efficiency of healthcare. Qual Saf Health Care 2010 Jun 16.
document.body:
Abstract

Problem Chronic kidney disease is increasingly recognised in the UK, leading to a greater demand for specialist services. Traditional means of meeting this demand rely on GP referral of patients to see a nephrologist. Hospital assessment may be inconvenient for patients and inefficient for health services.

Setting 17 general practices and a secondary care nephrology service in Bradford, UK.

Design A before and after evaluation comparing nephrology referrals from implementation and non-implementation practices following the introduction of electronic consultations (e-consultations) for chronic kidney disease. Key measures for improvement The number, appropriateness and quality of new referrals (paper and electronic) from primary care, the timeliness of responses and the satisfaction of patients and health professionals with the new service.

Strategies for change Electronic sharing of primary care electronic health records with the nephrology service was introduced to implementation practices. Participating GPs attended education workshops and received paper and e-guidance about the new service.

Effects of change There was a significant reduction in paper referrals from implementation practices. E-consultation provided nephrologists with access to more clinical information. GPs reported that the service was convenient, provided timely and helpful advice, and avoided outpatient referrals. Specialist recommendations were well followed, and GPs felt more confident about managing chronic kidney disease in the community.

Lessons learnt E-consultation promotes effective management of patients with mild-to-moderate chronic kidney disease in primary care, allowing specialist resources to be directed towards supporting patients with more complex needs. There is a potential role for e-consultation in other chronic disease specialties.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Kidney Diseases and Male Urogenital Disorders]]>
document.title: End-stage renal disease
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRANSPLANTATION,HAEMODIALYSIS,ACUTE KIDNEY INJURY,PERITONEAL DIALYSIS,COMPLICATIONS OF KIDNEY DISEASE,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE,KIDNEY DISEASES,DIALYSIS]]>
document.description: A BMJ Clinical Evidence topic
document.body:
Here is a list of clinical questions we have addressed in this review.

  • What are the effects of different doses for peritoneal dialysis?
  • What are the effects of different doses and membrane fluxes for haemodialysis?
  • What are the effects of interventions aimed at preventing secondary complications?

What are the effects of different doses for peritoneal dialysis?


Unlikely to be beneficial  

  • Increased-dose peritoneal dialysis (no more effective than standard-dose dialysis in reducing overall mortality)

What are the effects of different doses and membrane fluxes for haemodialysis?


Unlikely to be beneficial  

  • High membrane-flux haemodialysis (no more effective than low membrane-flux haemodialysis in reducing all-cause mortality)
  • Increased-dose haemodialysis (no more effective than standard-dose haemodialysis in reducing all-cause mortality)

What are the effects of interventions aimed at preventing secondary complications?


Likely to be beneficial  

  • Cinacalcet (improves control of secondary hyperparathyroidism compared with placebo)
  • Mupirocin (reduces Staphylococcus aureus catheter infections compared with placebo or no treatment)
  • Sevelamer (reduces progression of coronary artery and aortic calcification compared with calcium salts)

Trade off between benefits and harms  

  • Erythropoietin or darbepoetin (maintain haemoglobin levels but associated with increased mortality and cardiovascular events in people with cardiovascular disease)

Unknown effectiveness  

  • Statins in people with end-stage renal disease and normal lipid profiles
]]>

document.title: Enhanced surveillance of Meticillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PREVENTION OF INFECTIONS,PERITONEAL DIALYSIS,HAEMODIALYSIS,PREVENTION OF INFECTIONS,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY DISEASES,DIALYSIS]]>
document.description: All NHS Trusts in England are required by the Department of Health to report every episode of MRSA bacteraemia. These data are entered onto a web-based data capture system managed by the Health Protection Agency and Trusts rate of MRSA bacteraemia reported every quarter.
document.body:
All NHS Trusts in England are required by the Department of Health to report every episode of MRSA bacteraemia. These data are entered onto a web based data capture system managed by the Health Protection Agency and Trusts rate of MRSA bacteraemia reported every quarter.
http://www.hpa.org.uk/web/HPAwebFile/HPAweb_C/1229502457803

A significant proportion of these MRSA bacteraemias occur in patients receiving dialysis. For this reason, in 2007 the facility to capture additional data on those patients with MRSA bacteraemia and in established renal failure was added to the system for reporting MRSA bacteraemia. http://www.hpa.org.uk/web/HPAwebFile/HPAweb_C/1194947399620

In the first year of this enhanced surveillance 188 MRSA bacteraemia were reported in patients in established renal failure (ERF) and the data was analysed and reported in conjunction with the UK Renal Registry. http://www.online.karger.com/ProdukteDB/produkte.asp?Doi=210001

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Kidney Diseases and Male Urogenital Disorders]]>
document.title: Epoetins and the risk of tumour growth progression and thromboembolic events in cancer patients and cardiovascular risks in patients with chronic kidney disease
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLICATIONS OF KIDNEY DISEASE,ANAEMIA,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.description: Public statement from European Medicines Agency
document.body:
Extract

The European Medicines Agency is reviewing the safety of all centrally-authorised epoetins. The safety review has been initiated because new data from both unpublished and published studies suggest an increased risk of serious cardiovascular complications in patients with chronic renal failure. Epoetins are used for the treatment of anaemia in patients with chronic renal failure.

 

]]>

  • Kaminetsky, J. (2006). "Comorbid LUTS and erectile dysfunction: optimizing their management." Curr Med Res Opin 22(12): 2497-506. [Link to PubMed abstract]
  • Montorsi, P., P. M. Ravagnani, et al. (2006). "Association between erectile dysfunction and coronary artery disease: Matching the right target with the right test in the right patient." Eur Urol 50(4): 721-31. [Link to PubMed abstract]

 

]]>

document.title: Ethnicity and renal failure: disparity or diversity
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PREDISPOSING FACTORS,ETHNIC GROUP,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE,KIDNEY DISEASES,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.description: A National Symposium in 2003
document.body:
Extract from website

The symposium outlined the current epidemiological data on ethnicity, identified causal factors and presented innovative UK and American initiatives designed to reach and treat ‘at risk’ groups. The aim of the symposium was to raise the profile of the Ethnicity and Diversity in Renal Failure and to promote the concept of inclusive and networked care as away to tackle primary prevention, organ donation, health planning and health provision.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Kidney Diseases and Male Urogenital Disorders]]>
document.title: Europeans and organ donations
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ASSESSMENT/SELECTION,TRANSPLANTATION,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.description: Eurobarometer report from the European Commission
document.body:
Proposals for a European organ donor card, to tackle record waiting lists for transplants published in a European Commission report May 30th 2007.

Britain has one of the highest family refusal rates in the EU, with 42 per cent of relatives blocking organ removal, compared with 17 per cent in Spain, 29 per cent in Italy and 30 per cent in France.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Kidney Diseases and Male Urogenital Disorders]]>
document.title: EUVAS
document.topics: <![CDATA[ NEW RESEARCH,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.description: Details of the European Vasculitis Study Group actvities
document.body:
Trials actively recruiting:

  • PEXIVAS (Plasma exchange and glucocorticoid dosing in the treatment of ANCA-associated vasculitis) This is the largest international multicentre trial so far. The first patients will be included in Spring 2010.
  • MYCYC (Randomised clinical trial of mycophenolate mofetil versus cyclophosphamide for remission induction in ANCA associated vasculitis). The first patient was included in June 2007. A report on MYCYC's progress appears regularly.
  • REMAIN (long-term low dose immunosuppression versus treatment withdrawal for renal vasculitis). The protocol was revised in January 2006.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Kidney Diseases and Male Urogenital Disorders]]>
document.title: Everolimus in Patients with Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease
document.topics: <![CDATA[ POLYCYSTIC KIDNEY DISEASE,IN ADULTS,INHERITED KIDNEY DISEASE,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.body:
433 patients with ADPKD were randomly assigned to either placebo or mTOR inhibitor everolimus over two years. The authors conclude that "everolimus slowed the increase in total kidney volume of patients with ADPKD but did not slow the decline in progressive renal impairment", compared to placebo.

(EudraCT number, 2006-001485-16; ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00414440 [ClinicalTrials.gov] .)

Walz G, Budde K, Mannaa M, Nurnberger J, Wanner C, Sommerer C, et al. "Everolimus in Patients with Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease." New England Journal of Medicine. Published online June 26, 2010 (10.1056/NEJMoa1003491)

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Kidney Diseases and Male Urogenital Disorders]]>
document.title: Evidence based practice guidelines for the nutritional management of CKD
document.topics: <![CDATA[ INTERVENTIONS,DIETARY CHANGE,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.description: Guidelines published in Nutrition and Dietetics 2006, Vol 63, supp 2, by the Dietitians Association of Australia
document.body:
Extract

The purpose of these guidelines is to provide dietitians with a summary of evidence based clinical guidelines related to the dietetic management of adult patients with chronic kidney disease. The patient target group is any adult patient fulfilling the definition and diagnostic criteria of Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD), excluding those with nephrotic syndrome. These guidelines by definition also exclude acute renal failure and transplantation.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Kidney Diseases and Male Urogenital Disorders]]>
document.title: Evidence-based treatment recommendations for uraemic bleeding
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLICATIONS OF KIDNEY DISEASE,OTHER,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.description: Review published in Nature Clinical Practice Nephrology 2007; 3: 138-153
document.body:
Extract from article

A review published in Nature Clinical Practice Nephrology has described the pathophysiology and management of uraemic bleeding syndrome. The review describes the evidence base for the following treatment options:

  • dialysis
  • erythropoietin
  • cryoprecipitate
  • desmopressin, and
  • conjugated estrogens


Additionally, the review presents an evidence-based treatment algorithm to help guide clinicians through most clinical scenarios to manage the condition

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Kidney Diseases and Male Urogenital Disorders]]>
document.title: Exercise and kidney diseases: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders
document.topics: <![CDATA[ OTHERS,INTERVENTIONS,CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.body:
111-1Exercise and kidney diseases: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses

NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders has identified the following resources relevant to this topic area. We perform systematic searches to identify up-to-date, high quality evidence for a given topic. View our content development strategy for more information.

Users should note that we have not performed an in-depth appraisal for each reference but have applied rigorous methods to select them.  Where pre-appraisals exist, we link to them.   We recommend that a full appraisal is completed using the appropriate check-list provided by the Centre for Evidence-Based Medicine.  We welcome feedback about resources that we identify, do contact us if you would like to comment.

 

References:

 

2010

  • Afshinnia, F., T. J. Wilt, et al. (2010). "Weight loss and proteinuria: Systematic review of clinical trials and comparative cohorts." Nephrology Dialysis Transplantation 25(4): 1173-1183. [Link to PubMed abstract]
  • Bennett, P. N., L. Breugelmans, et al. (2010). "Sustaining a hemodialysis exercise program: a review." Seminars in Dialysis 23(1): 62-73. [Link to PubMed abstract]
  • Johansen, K. L., F. O. Finkelstein, et al. (2010). "Systematic review and meta-analysis of exercise tolerance and physical functioning in dialysis patients treated with erythropoiesis-stimulating agents." American Journal of Kidney Diseases 55(3): 535-48. [Link to PubMed abstract]
  • Segura-Orti, E. (2010). "Exercise in haemodialysis patients: a literature systematic review [Spanish] Ejercicio en pacientes en hemodialisis: revision sistematica de la literatura." Nefrologia : publicacion oficial de la Sociedad Espanola Nefrologia 30(2): 236-246. [Link to PubMed abstract]

 

2009

  • Gillison, F. B., S. M. Skevington, et al. (2009). "The effects of exercise interventions on quality of life in clinical and healthy populations; a meta-analysis." Social Science and Medicine 68(9): 1700-1710. [Link to PubMed abstract]
  • Macdonald, J. H., D. Kirkman, et al. (2009). "Kidney transplantation: a systematic review of interventional and observational studies of physical activity on intermediate outcomes." Adv Chronic Kidney Dis 16(6): 482-500. [Link to DARE abstract]
  • Navaneethan, S. D., H. Yehnert, et al. (2009). "Weight loss interventions in chronic kidney disease: a systematic review and meta-analysis." Clin J Am Soc Nephrol 4(10): 1565-74. [Link to PubMed abstract]

 

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.body:
111-1Newsletter

The Kidney Diseases Specialist Library is for busy health professionals, providing them with high quality information and keeping them up to date with the latest research and developments in this area.

   

New resources in January 2009:

Guidance

  • The CKD eGuide has been updated - Renal Association
  • Personal Health Budgets - Department of Health
  • New Guidelines for acute management of first presentation of renal or ureteric lithiasis - British Association of Urological Surgeons
  • New guidance on Machine perfusion systems and cold static storage of kidneys from deceased donors -  NICE
  • Commissioning guide on Supporting people with long term conditions and personalised care planning - Department of Health
  • Febuxostat for the management of hyperuricaemia in people with gout - NICE

Evidence

  • NEJM article on Long Term Consequences of Kidney Donation - New England Journal of Medicine Jan 29 2009
  • Interventions for haemolytic uraemic syndrome and thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura - The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews Issue 1 2009
  • Steroid avoidance or withdrawal for kidney transplant recipients - The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews Issue 1 2009
  • Reduced Glomerular Filtration Rate and Its Association with Clinical Outcome in Older Patients at Risk of Vascular Events Secondary Analysis - PLoS Med 2009
  • BMJ Clinical Review on the Assessment and management of nonvisible haematuria in primary care - BMJ 2009 338 a3021
  • Review published in the Lancet on eculizumab for paroxysmal nocturnal haemoglobinuria - The Lancet
  • A meta analysis on Interferon therapy for HCV-associated glomerulonephritis - Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects
  • A review of the effectiveness and safety of different hemodialysis modalities - Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects
  • Does warfarin safely prevent clotting of hemodialysis catheters a review of efficacy and safety - Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects
  • Combination therapy with an ACE inhibitor and an angiotensin receptor blocker for diabetic nephropathy a meta analysis - Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects
  • New UK DUETs website – UK Database of Uncertainties about the Effects of Treatment
  • New information about factors to consider when dosing patients with renal impairment - South West Medicines Information and Training

Reference

  • 18 week CKD pathways updated - 18 Weeks website
  • Renal NSF Update for December 2008 - NHS Kidney Care

Education/ CPD

  • Interactive case history from BMJ Learning on UTIs in Children - BMJ Learning

Patient information

  • New Kidney Disease Self Assessment tool - NHS Choices
  • New NHS Choices Guide on Understanding Kidney Disease - NHS Choices

 

Please take five minutes to fill in our new survey of library users: This is an eight-question survey which will provide vital information to the Kidney Diseases Specialist Library team. Link to the survey. 

]]>

document.body:
111-1February 2010 NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders newsletter

Welcome to the kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders specialist collection enewsletter for February 2010.

 

NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders is for busy health professionals, providing them with high quality information and keeping them up to date with the latest research and developments in this area. You can now join our mailing list to receive regular updates. Click here for the link.

 

 

***** Quick survey open to library users to find out what information you need and what you think of our Annual Evidence Updates and Treatment Uncertainties: http://www.surveymonkey.com/s/GGMQ5T8 *****

  

 

Links to:

  • New Kidney Diseases items
  • New Male Urogenital Disorders items

 

 RSS FEEDS 

 

You can receive news from the kidney diseases specialist collection from the RSS feeds we provide:

  1.  New Kidney Diseases Resources
  2.  New Male Urogenital Disorders Resources
  3.  Kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders in the news

Click through this link to find out more about RSS feeds.

 

JOURNALS

You can link through to the latest Tables of Contents from all the major kidney, transplant and urology journals from this page.

 

New resources added in January 2010

 

Chronic Kidney Disease

  • NEW website for NHS Kidney Care: http://www.kidneycare.nhs.uk/
  • Annual Evidence Update 18 January 2010: Patient and carer involvement in chronic disease. Contents page.
  • Interventions for bone disease in children with chronic kidney disease. Cochrane systematic review 2010.
  • Chronic Kidney Disease: frequently asked questions. Care pathway from NHS Employers.
  • What is the rationale and evidence for combining angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors with angiotensin II receptor blockers in renal disease? National electronic Library for Medicines (22/01/10).
  • Chronic Kidney Disease: Systematic Reviews and Meta-analyses.


Acute kidney injury

  • Hydroxyethyl starch (HES) versus other fluid therapies: effects on kidney function. Cochrane systematic review 2010.
  • Nutritional support for acute kidney injury. Cochrane systematic review 2010.
  • Acute Kidney Injury: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses

Hypertension

  • Roselle for hypertension in adults. Cochrane systematic review 2010.

Renovascular disease

  • Aprotinin and the risk of death and renal dysfunction in patients undergoing cardiac surgery: a meta-analysis of epidemiologic studies. DARE abstract.
  • Renovascular disease: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses

Diabetic nephropathy

  • Diabetic Nephropathy: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses

Dialysis

  • Let's talk renal rubbish. Podcast from the Campaign for Greener Healthcare.
  • Conserving water in haemodialysis: case study and how-to guide. Campaign for Greener Healthcare.
  • Interventions for preventing infectious complications in haemodialysis patients with central venous catheters.  Cochrane systematic review 2010.
  • Kidney dialysis: developing costs to deliver an equitable and high quality service; final report. Department of Health commissioning report.
  • Renal Association guidelines – haemodialysis. Published 2007, updated December 2009.

Transplantation

  • A meta-analysis of mini-open versus standard open and laparoscopic living donor nephrectomy - DARE abstract.
  • Renal transplant: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses

Kidney Cancer

  • Risk of sarcopenia with sorafenib in patients with advanced renal cell carcinoma National electronic Library for Medicines (20/01/10).
  • NHS Health Technology Assessment: Bevacizumab, sorafenib and sunitinib for renal cell carcinoma. National electronic Library for Medicines (13/01/10).
  • Kidney cancer: systematic reviews and meta-analyses

Kidney stones

  • Kidney stones: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses

 

Male Urogenital Disorders

Male Bladder Disorders

  • Ancillary bladder tumor-associated antigen (BTA) testing for bladder cancer screening and detection. HTA.
  • Ancillary hyaluronic acid (HA)/Hyaluronidase (HAase) testing for bladder cancer screening and detection. HTA.
  • Ancillary ImmunoCyt/uCyt+ testing for bladder cancer screening and detection. HTA.
  • Ancillary nuclear matrix protein 22 (NMP22) testing for bladder cancer screening and detection. HTA.
  • Ancillary urinary cytokeratin (CK) tests for bladder cancer screening and detection. HTA.
  • Ancillary urinary microsatellite analysis (MA) for bladder cancer screening and detection. HTA.
  • Ancillary urinary survivin testing for bladder cancer screening and detection. HTA.
  • Ancillary urinary telomerase testing for bladder cancer screening and detection. HTA.
  • Ancillary UroVysion fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) testing for bladder cancer screening and detection. HTA.
  • Electrical percutaneous tibial nerve stimulation for urinary voiding dysfunction. HTA.

Prostate Disorders

  • Active surveillance and radical prostatectomy for clinically localized, low-risk prostate cancer. HTA.
  • Prostate cancer false positive rate. News item from the NHS Improvement Network (13/01/10).
  • New systematic reviews identified by NHS Evidence - cancer.

Testicular/Scrotal Disorders

  • Systematic review: Management of Stage I Seminomatous Testicular Cancer: a Systematic Review, 2009.

Male Urinary Incontinence

  • 2010 Annual Evidence Update on Male Urinary Incontinence - link to contents page

Sexually Transmitted Infections

  • Cognitive-behavioral stress management interventions for persons living with HIV: a review and critique of the literature. DARE abstract.
  • Directly observed antiretroviral therapy: a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomised clinical trials. DARE abstract.
  • Effects and effectiveness of life skills education for HIV prevention in young people. DARE abstract.
  • Massage therapy for people with HIV/AIDS. Cochrane systematic review 2010.
  • Psychosocial interventions for reducing injection and sexual risk behaviour for preventing HIV in drug users. Cochrane systematic review 2010.

 

Fertility

  • Infertility provision in England. Published December 2009. Guideline from the Royal College of Nursing.

 

 

 

**Subscribe to the NHS Evidence Eyes on Evidence Newsletter**


If you would like to receive Eyes on Evidence, the monthly e-bulletin from NHS Evidence, please sign up at http://www.evidence.nhs.uk/NewsletterSignup.aspx.


The bulletin will keep you updated with new and important evidence and key developments on the NHS Evidence portal.  It comes out on the second Wednesday of the month and can be sent to any e-mail address that you provide.

]]>

document.title: February 2011 NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders newsletter
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders
document.topics: <![CDATA[ KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.body:
111-1February 2011 NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders newsletter

Welcome to the kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders specialist collection enewsletter for FEBRUARY 2011.

NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders is for busy health professionals, providing them with high quality information and keeping them up to date with the latest research and developments in this area. 

 

New this month:

  • New mini topic review on Recent Clinical Trials in Adult Polycystic Kidney Disease.
  • 2011 Annual Evidence Update on Male Urinary Incontinence.
  • 2011 Annual Evidence Update on Female Urinary Incontinence.

**Please note - this newsletter will no longer be provided from 1st April 2011.**

Links to:

  • New Kidney Diseases items
  • New Male Urogenital Disorders items

  

FEBRUARY 2011: RENAL HOT TOPICS

 

JAMA

  • Thomas F. Hiemstra, Michael Walsh, Alfred Mahr, Caroline O. Savage, Kirsten de Groot, Lorraine Harper, Thomas Hauser, Irmgard Neumann, Vladimir Tesar, Karl-Martin Wissing, Christian Pagnoux, Wilhelm Schmitt, David R. W. Jayne , for the European Vasculitis Study Group (EUVAS). Mycophenolate Mofetil vs Azathioprine for Remission Maintenance in Antineutrophil Cytoplasmic Antibody–Associated Vasculitis: A Randomized Controlled Trial. JAMA. 2010;304(21):2381-2388. [Link to PubMed abstract]

156 patients randomly assigned to azathiopine or mycophenolate after standard induction treatment with cyclophosphamide. The primary endpoint was time to relapse, with relapse being more frequent in the mycophenolate group.

 

The Lancet

  • Matthew T James, Brenda R Hemmelgarn, Natasha Wiebe, Neesh Pannu, Braden J Manns, Scott W Klarenbach, Marcello Tonelli, for the Alberta Kidney Disease Network. Glomerular filtration rate, proteinuria, and the incidence and consequences of acute kidney injury: a cohort study. The Lancet 2010; 376: 2096-2104. [Link to PubMed abstract]

Cohort study of 920 985 adults residing in Alberta, Canada over a 5 year period. The presence of proteinuria was associated with a 4-fold increase in risk in admission to hospital, and  relatice increase in risk of requiring renal replacement therapy in AKI.

  • Symplicity HTN-2 Investigators.  Renal sympathetic denervation in patients with treatment-resistant hypertension (The Symplicity HTN-2 Trial): a randomised controlled trial. The Lancet 2010; 376:1903-1910. [Link to PubMed abstract]

In a multicentre, prospective, randomised trial, patients who had a baseline systolic blood pressure of 160 mm Hg or more (=150 mm Hg for patients with type 2 diabetes), despite taking three or more antihypertensive drugs, were randomly allocated in a one-to-one ratio to undergo renal denervation with previous treatment or to maintain previous treatment alone. At 6 months, 41 (84%) of 49 patients who underwent renal denervation had a reduction in systolic blood pressure of 10 mm Hg or more, compared with 18 (35%) of 51 controls (p<0•0001).

 

NEJM

  • The FHN Trial Group. In-Center Hemodialysis Six Times per Week versus Three Times per Week. N Engl J Med 2010; 363:2287-2300. [Link to PubMed abstract] 

Patients were randomly assigned to undergo hemodialysis six times per week (frequent hemodialysis, 125 patients) or three times per week (conventional hemodialysis, 120 patients) for 12 months. Frequent hemodialysis was associated with improved control of hypertension and hyperphosphatemia, although there was a higher requirement for access assessment and revision in this group, a potentially importance co-morbidity. Despite this, the hazard ratio for death and changes in LV mass were significantly lower in the frequently dialysed group.

 

CJASN

  • Kandula P, Dobre M, Schold JD, Schreiber MJ Jr, Mehrotra R, Navaneethan SD. Vitamin D Supplementation in Chronic Kidney Disease: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis of Observational Studies and Randomized Controlled Trials. CJASN January 2011 6): (1) 50-62; published ahead of print September 28, 2010, doi:10.2215/CJN.03940510. [Link to PubMed abstract]

 


 

 RSS FEEDS 

 

You can receive news from the kidney diseases specialist collection from the RSS feeds we provide:

  1.  New Kidney Diseases Resources
  2.  New Male Urogenital Disorders Resources
  3.  Kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders in the news

Click through this link to find out more about RSS feeds.

 

JOURNALS

You can link through to the latest Tables of Contents from all the major kidney, transplant and urology journals from this page.

 

Resources added in January 2011

 

Chronic Kidney Disease

  • Kidney diseases evidence updated - systematic reviews and meta analyses.
  • Proteinuria Induced by Parenteral Iron in Chronic Kidney Disease - A Comparative Randomized Controlled Trial. New RCT published in the Clinical Journal of the American Society of Nephrology (CJASN).
  • Vitamin D Supplementation in Chronic Kidney Disease - A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis of Observational Studies and Randomized Controlled Trials. New systematic review published in the Clinical Journal of the American Society of Nephrology (CJASN).
  • Renal Tsar - How do quality accounts measure up? Dr Donal O'Donoghue (19/01/11).
  • Weight loss interventions in chronic kidney disease- a systematic review and meta-analysis. CRD Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.
  • Renal Tsar - The Care Record Guarantee. Dr Donal O'Donoghue (02/01/11).
  • Renal Tsar - Bumper return to the national vascular audit. Dr Donal O'Donoghue (02/01/11).
  • Educational interventions in kidney disease care- a systematic review of randomized trials. CRD Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.

Diabetic nephropathy

  • No new resources this month.

Hypertension

  • Pharmacist interventions to enhance blood pressure control and adherence to antihypertensive therapy- review and meta-analysis. National electronic Library for Medicines (24/01/11).
  • Pay for performance doesn't seem to improve quality of care in hypertension. National electronic Library for Medicines (27/01/11).
  • Meta-analysis- pharmacist interventions to improve anti-hypertensive adherence and BP control. National electronic Library for Medicines (25/01/11).
  • Drug treatment of hypertension - update search [rapid report]. CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Home blood pressure monitoring. CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Increase of physical activity in essential hypertension - rapid report. CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.

Acute kidney injury

  • Updated systematic reviews and meta analyses on Acute Kidney Injury.

End-Stage Renal Disease

  • The Lived Experiences of Children and Adolescents With End-Stage Renal Disease. A new article from Qualitative Health Research about children's perceptions of ESRD.

Renovascular diseases

  • No new resources this month.

Glomerulonephritis

  • The incidence of primary glomerulonephritis worldwide- a systematic review of the literature. A new systematic review published in Nephrol. Dial. Transplant.

Other renal conditions

  • Interventions for idiopathic steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome in children. A new Cochrane systematic review.
  • Daily Corticosteroids Reduce Infection-associated Relapses in Frequently Relapsing Nephrotic Syndrome - A Randomized Controlled Trial. New RCT published in the Clinical Journal of the American Society of Nephrology (CJASN).
  • New mini topic review on Recent Clinical Trials in Adult Polycystic Kidney Disease. This mini topic review covers six trials published in 2010 about adult polycystic kidney disease. Written by Dr Edward Sharples

Renal tract infections

  • Clinical Evidence topic - Acute pyelonephritis in non-pregnant women. Published by BMJ Clinical Evidence.

Kidney stones

  • Drugs for kidney stones. National electronic Library for Medicines (11/01/11)

Renal vasculitis

  • No new resources this month.

Haemodialysis

  • Sevelamer prescriptions after reporting of the Dialysis Clinical Outcomes Revisited -DCOR- Trial Findings. National electronic Library for Medicines (25/01/11).
  • Renal Tsar - Best Practice Tariff for Adult Haemodialysis. Dr Donal O'Donoghue (19/01/11).
  • Renal Tsar - Eliminating mixed sex accommodation - what does it mean for dialysis units. Dr Donal O'Donoghue (19/01/11).
  • Cost-effectiveness of frequent in-center hemodialysis. NHS Economic Evaluation Database.
  • Weekly alteplase better than heparin alone as a central catheter lock in haemodialysis. National electronic Library for Medicines (28/01/11).
  • New England Journal of Medicine editorial on Haemodialysis.

Peritoneal Dialysis

  • Update on European Medicines Agency review of the manufacture of Baxters peritoneal dialysis solutions and potential presence of endotoxins. National electronic Library for Medicines (24/01/11).
  • Renal Tsar - NICE Guideline on Peritoneal Dialysis. Dr Donal O'Donoghue (26/01/11).

Transplantation

  • SMC accepts valganciclovir for restricted use in prevention of CMV disease in solid organ transplant recipients. National electronic Library for Medicines (19/01/11).
  • Cardiac Testing for Coronary Artery Disease in Potential Kidney Transplant Recipients - A Systematic Review of Test Accuracy Studies. Systematic review published in the American Journal of Kidney Diseases.
  • Thyroid cancer and renal transplantation- a meta-analysis. CRD Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.
  • Valganciclovir for cytomegalovirus prevention in solid organ transplant patients- an evidence-based reassessment of safety and efficacy. CRD Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.

Kidney Cancer

  • Bevacizumab (first-line), sorafenib (first- and second-line), sunitinib (second-line) and temsirolimus (first-line) for the treatment of advanced and/or metastatic renal cell carcinoma. CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Sunitinib for the first-line treatment of advanced and or metastatic renal cell carcinoma. CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.

 

Male Urogenital Disorders

  • BAUS President's Newsletter for January 2011.
  • The management of lower urinary tract symptoms in men commissioning guide. NICE Commissioning Guide.

Male Ureteric Disorders

  • No new resources this month.

Male Bladder Disorders

  • Photodynamic diagnosis in non-muscle-invasive bladder cancer- a systematic review and cumulative analysis of prospective studies. CRD Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.
  • L-methionine in patients with neurogenic bladder disorders. CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.

Prostate Disorders

  • New CKS topics on Prostate cancer. Clinical Knowledge Summaries.
  • Protein may fight prostate cancer. A Behind the Headlines analysis of recent news articles. (02/02/11).
  • The most often used androgen receptor blockers in prostate cancer - systematic review. CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Denosumab for the treatment of therapy-induced bone loss in non-metastatic prostate cancer - terminated appraisal. CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Interstitial brachytherapy in localised prostate cancer - rapid report. CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Non-drug local procedures for treatment of benign prostatic syndrome - Update - rapid report. CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Open laparoscopic and robot-assisted laparoscopic radical prostatectomy for localised prostate cancer. CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Management of chronic prostatitis or chronic pelvic pain syndrome- a systematic review and network meta-analysis. CRD Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.

Penile Disorders

  • Penile cancer systematic reviews. New systematic reviews identified by the team at NHS Evidence - cancer.

Urethral disorders

  • No new resources this month.

Urinary tract infections

  • No new resources this month.

Testicular/Scrotal Disorders

  • Protection from scrotal hyperthermia in laptop computer users. National electronic Library for Medicines (28/01/11).
  • Clinical Evidence topic - Testicular cancer - seminoma.

Male Urinary Incontinence

  • New RCT - Behavioral Therapy With or Without Biofeedback and Pelvic Floor Electrical Stimulation for Persistent Postprostatectomy Incontinence. By Goode PS et al.
  • 2011 Annual Evidence Update on Male Urinary Incontinence. Links to contents page.
  • New CKS topics on Enuresis. Clinical Knowledge Summaries.

Sexually Transmitted Infections

  • Cost-effectiveness of nationwide hepatitis B catch-up vaccination among children and adolescents in China. NHS Economic Evaluation Database.
  • A cost-effectiveness analysis of the Chlamydia Monday- a community-based intervention to decrease the prevalence of chlamydia in Sweden. NHS Economic Evaluation Database.
  • Interventions to modify sexual risk behaviours for preventing HIV in homeless youth. A new Cochrane systematic review.
  • Sperm washing to prevent HIV transmission from HIV-infected men but allowing conception in sero-discordant couples. A new Cochrane systematic review.
  • Antiretroviral therapy for HIV infection in patients naive to prior treatment- a systematic review of effectiveness and cost-effectiveness. CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Tenofovir disoproxil for the treatment of chronic hepatitis B. CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.

Fertility

  • Antioxidants for male subfertility. A new Cochrane systematic review.

document.description: A review article from Cell Mol Life Sci 2006, 63, (21) p2506-11
document.body:
Extract from abstract

An increasing cause of end-stage renal disease is the pathological lesion focal and segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS). FSGS is characterized by proteinuria and frequently nephrotic syndrome with ensuing renal failure

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Kidney Diseases and Male Urogenital Disorders]]>
document.title: Focus on: preparing for end stage renal disease
document.publisher: NHS Institute for Innovation and Improvement
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRANSPLANTATION,ACUTE KIDNEY INJURY,HAEMODIALYSIS,PERITONEAL DIALYSIS,END-OF-LIFE CARE,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE,KIDNEY DISEASES,DIALYSIS]]>
document.description: The aim of this project is to identify clinical pathways and processes that give renal patients easier, more efficient access to their chosen treatment option.
document.body:
As part of the project we are examining the following issues:

  • planning a pre-emptive transplant – options,choice and education
  • planning the transplant assessment
  • preparing the patient and their relatives, carers and potential donor for dialysis and therapy options
  • how a multi-skilled renal team impacts on the pathway and ensures timely interventions
  • the organisation of processes and information throughout the patient journey
  • evidence of support and guidance for service development provided by trusts and commissioners.
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Kidney Diseases and Male Urogenital Disorders]]>
document.title: Freeman Hospital Newcastle upon Tyne Transplantation Unit
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRANSPLANTATION,TRANSPLANT CENTRES,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.description: Webpage giving contacts and background. A new dedicated renal medicine centre is due to be opened in 2008.
document.body:
Extract from website

Renal transplantation is managed jointly by physicians and surgeons which started with live renal transplantation in the mid 1960's and has developed into a leading renal transplant and research unit. The unit has an active programme of living related and living unrelated transplantation and has developed cadaveric renal transplantation research into organ donation and renal preservation. An active research programme to transplant immunology and rejection associated with the University of Newcastle upon Tyne Medical School.


Educational Opportunities

Education links to the University of Northumbria and University of Newcastle upon Tyne provide opportunities for the development of all staff. Speciality nursing, medical undergraduate and postgraduate education and training.


The Future

As part of the agreed PFI project for modernising the Newcastle hospitals a new dedicated renal/renal transplant unit is being built (due to open 2008).

]]>

document.body:
111-1Genetics of Kidney Diseases: Systematic Reviews and Meta-analyses

NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders has identified the following resources relevant to this topic area. We perform systematic searches to identify up-to-date, high quality evidence for a given topic. View our content development strategy for more information.

Users should note that we have not performed an in-depth appraisal for each reference but have applied rigorous methods to select them.  Where pre-appraisals exist, we link to them.   We recommend that a full appraisal is completed using the appropriate check-list provided by the Centre for Evidence-Based Medicine.  We welcome feedback about resources that we identify, do contact us if you would like to comment.

 

References:

 

2011

  • Mooyaart AL, Valk EJ, van Es LA, Bruijn JA, de Heer E, Freedman BI, et al. Genetic associations in diabetic nephropathy: a meta-analysis. Diabetologia. 2011;54(3):544-53. [Link to PubMed abstract]

document.name: <![CDATA[ Kidney Diseases and Male Urogenital Disorders]]>
document.title: Global Dialysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HAEMODIALYSIS,LIVING WITH DIALYSIS,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY DISEASES,DIALYSIS]]>
document.description: Website featuring single, free to use, directory of dialysis centres. The directory is the largest database of dialysis centres in the world.
document.body:
Extract

Originally launched in January 2000 by Valda and Russell England, Global Dialysis was born out of the frustrations of trying to find dialysis centres for travelling. Information was gathered from the worldwide dialysis community with the aim of creating a single, free to use, directory of dialysis centres.

The directory of dialysis centres has steadily grown to over 14,000 in 154 countries making it the largest database of dialysis centres available in the world.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Kidney Diseases and Male Urogenital Disorders]]>
document.title: Guidelines for bone metabolism and disease in chronic kidney disease (adults)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLICATIONS OF KIDNEY DISEASE,BONE DISEASE,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.description: K/DOQI Clinical Practice Guideline
document.body:
Extract from guidelines

Disturbances in mineral and bone metabolism are common in patients with CKD. A large body of evidence indicates that these derangements are associated with increased mortality and morbidity. These patients have bone pain, increased incidence of bone fractures and deformity, myopathy and muscle pain, and ruptures of tendons. Hyperphosphatemia also appears to be associated with increased mortality, and elevated blood levels of PTH exert significant adverse effects on the function of almost every organ.

Importantly, the long-term effects of these derangements on soft tissue calcification have become an area of growing concern in the care of CKD patients. Calcification of the lung leads to impaired pulmonary function, pulmonary fibrosis, pulmonary hypertension, right ventricular hypertrophy, and right-side congestive heart failure. Calcification of the myocardium, coronary arteries, and cardiac valves results in congestive heart failure, cardiac arrhythmias, ischemic heart disease, and death. Vascular calcification leads to ischemic lesions, soft-tissue necrosis, and difficulties for kidney transplantation.

The processes causing disordered mineral metabolism and bone disease have their onset in the early stages of CKD, continue throughout the course of progressive loss of kidney function, and may be influenced beneficially or adversely by the various therapeutic approaches now used. Thus, prevention of the disturbances in mineral and bone metabolism and their management early in the course of chronic kidney disease are extremely important in improving the quality of life and longevity of CKD patients.

The present clinical practice guidelines were developed to provide an integrated clinical action plan to the management of this complex problem throughout the course of CKD.

 

]]>

document.title: Guidelines for the control and monitoring of microbiological contamination in water for dialysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HAEMODIALYSIS,PERITONEAL DIALYSIS,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,DIALYSIS,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.description: Guideline from EDTNA/ERCA
document.body:
These guidelines apply to the control and monitoring of microbiological contamination in:

  • water used for preparation of dialysis fluid in all settings, including patients’ homes and acute care units
  • water used for in-house production of liquid concentrates
  • water used for reprocessing dialysers
  • water used for preparation of ultrapure dialysis fluid by equipment fitted with additional point-of-use filtration
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Kidney Diseases and Male Urogenital Disorders]]>
document.title: Guy's and St Thomas' Hospital Renal Unit
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRANSPLANT CENTRES,TRANSPLANTATION,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.description: Background information on renal services
document.body:
Extract from website

Transplants
The unit is the major transplant unit for South East Thames, transplanting patients for both the King’s and Kent and Canterbury Renal Units.  Last year, the unit carried out 114 transplant operations, a growing number of which receive kidneys from a living donor.  The Trust has one of the largest living donor kidney transplant programme in the UK and a nurse consultant has recently been appointed to facilitate future service developments in this area of transplantation.

]]>

document.description: This section features examples of best practice, sample job descriptions, case studies, plus supporting documentation and links.
document.body:
Skills for Health - Workforce Projects Team (WPT) are leading the way in providing integrated workforce planning solutions in long term conditions. Supporting, caring for and treating people with long term conditions is expected to become one of the dominant healthcare themes of the 21st Century and WPT have been commissioned by the Department of Health to provide resources, tools and information.

To find out more about renal and other long term conditions, visit www.healthcareworkforce.nhs.uk/renal.

]]>

document.title: Henoch-Schönlein purpura: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders
document.topics: <![CDATA[ KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,COMPLICATIONS OF KIDNEY DISEASE,KIDNEY DISEASE IN CHILDREN AND ADOLESCENTS,GLOMERULONEPHRITIS,SECONDARY GLOMERULAR DISEASE,OTHER,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.body:
111-1Henoch-Schönlein purpura: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses

NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders has identified the following resources relevant to this topic area. We perform systematic searches to identify up-to-date, high quality evidence for a given topic. View our content development strategy for more information.

Users should note that we have not performed an in-depth appraisal for each reference but have applied rigorous methods to select them.  Where pre-appraisals exist, we link to them.   We recommend that a full appraisal is completed using the appropriate check-list provided by the Centre for Evidence-Based Medicine.  We welcome feedback about resources that we identify, do contact us if you would like to comment.

 

References:

 

2010

  • Han, S. S., H. K. Sun, et al. (2010). "Outcome of renal allograft in patients with henoch-schonlein nephritis: Single-center experience and systematic review." Transplantation 89(6): 721-726. [Link to PubMed abstract]

 

2009

  • Chartapisak, W., S. Opastiraku, et al. (2009). "Prevention and treatment of renal disease in Henoch-Schönlein purpura: a systematic review." Arch Dis Child 94(2): 132-7. [Link to PubMed abstract]
  • Chartapisak, W., S. Opastirakul, et al. (2009). "Interventions for preventing and treating kidney disease in Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP)." Cochrane Database Syst Rev(3): CD005128. [Link to Cochrane abstract]
  • Zaffanello, M., M. Brugnara, et al. (2009). "Adjuvant treatments for Henoch-Schönlein purpura nephritis in children: A systematic review." Current Therapeutic Research - Clinical and Experimental 70(3): 254-265. [Link to abstract]

 

2008

No systematic reviews.

 

2007

  • Weiss, P. F., J. A. Feinstein, et al. (2007). "Effects of corticosteroid on Henoch-Schönlein purpura: a systematic review." Pediatrics 120(5): 1079-87. [Link to PubMed abstract]
  • Zaffanello, M., M. Brugnara, et al. (2007). "Therapy for children with henoch-schönlein purpura nephritis: a systematic review." ScientificWorldJournal 7: 20-30. [Link to PubMed abstract]

 

2006

No systematic reviews.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Kidney Diseases and Male Urogenital Disorders]]>
document.title: High intensity focused ultrasound treatment (HIFU) for kidney cancer that cannot be removed with an operation
document.topics: <![CDATA[ NEW RESEARCH,RENAL CANCER,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.description: Details about HIFU
document.body:
Extract from website

High intensity ultrasound beams can kill body cells if the beam is focused directly onto them using a special machine. Doctors hope that HIFU can be used to treat kidney cancer without damaging healthy cells, but they are not sure yet how well this will work.

There has been a clinical trial in the UK looking at HIFU for kidney cancer that can't be removed by an operation. And another trial looking at HIFU before surgery. These trials are no longer recruiting and the results are awaited.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Kidney Diseases and Male Urogenital Disorders]]>
document.title: Hindu Dharma and organ donation
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRANSPLANTATION,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.description: A guide to organ donation and hindu dharma
document.body:
Extract from website

There are many references that support the concept of organ donation in Hindu scriptures. Daan is the original word in Sanskrit for donation meaning selfless giving. In the list of the ten Niyamas (virtuous acts) Daan comes third.

Hindi, Gujarati, and Punjabi translations are available.

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,PENILE DISORDERS,MALE SEXUALLY TRANSMITTED INFECTIONS,VIRAL,HIV,MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,CIRCUMCISION]]>
document.body:
111-1HIV and male urogenital disorders: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses

NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders has identified the following resources relevant to this topic area. We perform systematic searches to identify up-to-date, high quality evidence for a given topic. View our content development strategy for more information.

Users should note that we have not performed an in-depth appraisal for each reference but have applied rigorous methods to select them.  Where pre-appraisals exist, we link to them.   We recommend that a full appraisal is completed using the appropriate check-list provided by the Centre for Evidence-Based Medicine.  We welcome feedback about resources that we identify, do contact us if you would like to comment.

 

References:

 

2011

  • Blank LJ, Rompalo AM, Erbelding EJ, Zenilman JM, Ghanem KG. Treatment of syphilis in HIV-infected subjects: A systematic review of the literature. Sexually Transmitted Infections. 2011;87(1):9-16. [Link to PubMed abstract]
