document.name: <![CDATA[ Kidney Diseases and Male Urogenital Disorders]]>
document.title: How to measure renal function in clinical practice
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ASSESSMENT TESTS,ASSESSMENT OF RENAL FUNCTION,SCREENING TESTS,SCREENING OPTIONS,CREATININE CLEARANCE,GFR AND EGFR,CREATININE,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.description: This article in the BMJ describes routine and more specialised methods of assessing renal function and discusses estimated glomerular filtration rate
document.body:
Extract from the National electronic Library for Medicines website

The following topics are discussed:

  • Creatinine
  • Creatinine clearance
  • Urea
  • Mean of urea and creatinine clearance
  • Inulin clearance
  • Radioisotopic methods
  • Radiocontrast agents
  • Cystatin C
  • Prediction formulas
  • Cockcroft and Gault equation
  • Modification of diet in renal disease formula



The review advises that estimated GFR should be used as a guide to renal function in conjunction with advice on renal disease from the Renal Association's website (www.renal.org/eGFR/). It also provides the following tips for non-specialists if the estimated glomerular filtration rate is < 60 ml/min:

  • Review previous results or repeat the measurement to assess if renal function is stable or declining
  • Measure BP and test urine for protein and blood
  • Review drugs for potentially nephrotoxic agents, such as ACE inhibitors or AII receptor blockers, diuretics, NSAIDs, and antibiotics.
  • Check for urinary symptoms, signs of fluid retention or hypovolaemia, and palpable bladder
  • Enter into a chronic disease management programme and decide whether referral to a renal clinic is appropriate, using local guidelines or those from the Renal Association
]]>

111-1Hypertension: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses

NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders has identified the following resources relevant to this topic area. We perform systematic searches to identify up-to-date, high quality evidence for a given topic. View our content development strategy for more information.

Users should note that we have not performed an in-depth appraisal for each reference but have applied rigorous methods to select them.  Where pre-appraisals exist, we link to them.   We recommend that a full appraisal is completed using the appropriate check-list provided by the Centre for Evidence-Based Medicine.  We welcome feedback about resources that we identify, do contact us if you would like to comment.

document.body:
111-1Hypospadias: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses

NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders has identified the following resources relevant to this topic area. We perform systematic searches to identify up-to-date, high quality evidence for a given topic. View our content development strategy for more information.

Users should note that we have not performed an in-depth appraisal for each reference but have applied rigorous methods to select them.  Where pre-appraisals exist, we link to them.   We recommend that a full appraisal is completed using the appropriate check-list provided by the Centre for Evidence-Based Medicine.  We welcome feedback about resources that we identify, do contact us if you would like to comment.

 

References:

 

2010

  • Castagnetti, M. and A. El-Ghoneimi (2010). "Surgical management of primary severe hypospadias in children: Systematic 20-year review." Journal of Urology 184(4): 1469-1474. [Link to PubMed abstract]
  • Wilkinson, D. J., P. Farrelly, et al. (2010). "Outcomes in distal hypospadias: A systematic review of the Mathieu and tubularized incised plate repairs." J Pediatr Urol. Dec 13 [Epub ahead of print] [Link to PubMed abstract]
  • Yiee, J. H. and L. S. Baskin (2010). "Environmental factors in genitourinary development." Journal of Urology 184(1): 34-41. [Link to PubMed abstract]

 

2009

2008

document.description: Publication from Department of Health
document.body:
Extract

This Report follows the Renal Action Learning Sets Sharing Event in January 2006. It provides a summary of the work of the learning sets and includes a note from the project lead and the national facilitator as well as the slides from the day. Also included is some valuable information which resulted from the lively discussions which took place on the day.

]]>

document.description: Improving Choice for Kidney Patients: Home Haemodialysis February 2010
document.body:
Contents:

  • Foreword by National Clinical Director for Kidney Care
  • Introduction by Director, NHS Kidney Care
  • 1. Executive Summary
  • 2. Background
  • 2.1 Provision of Home Haemodialysis across England
  • 2.2 A Summary of the Clinical Evidence
  • 3. Perceived Barriers to improving choice for kidney patients
  • 3.1 What Works in Renal Units

document.name: <![CDATA[ Kidney Diseases and Male Urogenital Disorders]]>
document.title: Improving Choice: Listening to Patient Stories
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PERITONEAL DIALYSIS,HAEMODIALYSIS,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY DISEASES,DIALYSIS,HOME HAEMODIALYSIS,HOME DIALYSIS]]>
document.description: In order to try and increase the numbers of patients who are given the option to dialyse at home, NHS Kidney Care has launched a report: "Improving Choice: Listening to Patient Stories". There are also two short films, which show the stories of home dialysis patients and their partners.
document.body:
Contents of the report includes the following:

  • Foreword
  • Background
  • How do people discover home dialysis?
  • What factors influence the decision to dialyse at home?
  • What training is required for home dialysis?
  • What adaptation is required for home dialysis?
  • What are the advantages of dialysing at home?
  • What are the costs and challenges of dialysing at home?
  • What improvements are yet to be made?
  • What advice would those using home dialysis give to those considering it?
  • Summary

Link to webpage with short films: Listening to patient stories

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Kidney Diseases and Male Urogenital Disorders]]>
document.title: Improving surveillance of MRSA bacteraemia
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PREVENTION OF INFECTIONS,HAEMODIALYSIS,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,DIALYSIS,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.description: Editorial from British Medical Journal, 2005, 331, 976-977
document.body:
Extract from editorial

Lack of timely access to surgery to create arterio-venous fistulae for dialysis, resulting in prolonged use of intravenous lines,is a risk factor for infection in renal units.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Kidney Diseases and Male Urogenital Disorders]]>
document.title: Intradialytic versus home based exercise training in hemodialysis patients: a randomised controlled trial
document.topics: <![CDATA[ NEW RESEARCH,HAEMODIALYSIS,LIVING WITH DIALYSIS,PREVENTION OF INFECTIONS,ACCESS,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY DISEASES,DIALYSIS,HOME HAEMODIALYSIS]]>
document.description: A study protocol.
document.body:
Abstract extract

Background

Exercise training in hemodialysis patients improves fitness, physical function, quality of life and markers of cardiovascular disease such as arterial stiffness. The majority of trials investigating this area have used supervised exercise training during dialysis (intradialytic), which may not be feasible for some renal units. The aim of this trial is to compare the effects of supervised intradialytic with unsupervised home-based exercise training on physical function and arterial stiffness.


Methods and design

This is a randomised, controlled clinical trial. A total of 72 hemodialysis patients will be randomised to receive either six months of intradialytic exercise training, home-based exercise training or usual care. Intradialytic patients will undergo three training sessions per week on a cycle ergometer and home-based patients will be provided with a walking program to achieve the same weekly physical activity. Primary outcome measures are six-minute walk distance (6 MWD) and aortic pulse wave velocity (PWV). Secondary outcome measures include augmentation index, peripheral and central blood pressures, physical activity and self-reported health. Measures will be made at baseline, three and six months.


Discussion

The results of this study will help determine the efficacy of home-based exercise training in hemodialysis patients. This may assist in developing exercise guidelines specific for these patients.


Trial Registration

ACTRN12608000247370

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Kidney Diseases and Male Urogenital Disorders]]>
document.title: Islam and organ donation
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRANSPLANTATION,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.description: A guide to organ donations within muslim beliefs
document.body:
Extract from website

One of the basic aims of the Muslim faith is the saving of life. This is a fundamental aim of the Shariah and Allah greatly rewards those who save others from death.

Violating the human body, whether living or dead, is normally forbidden in Islam. The Shariah, however, waives this prohibition in a number of instances: firstly in cases of necessity; and secondly in saving another person's life. It is this Islamic legal maxim al-darurat tubih al-mahzurat (necessities overrule prohibition) that has great relevance to organ donation.

The Muslim Law (Shariah) Council of Great Britain resolved that:

  • the medical profession is the proper authority to define signs of death
  • current medical knowledge considers brain stem death to be a proper definition of death
  • the council accepts brain stem death as constituting the end of life for the purpose of organ transplantation
  • the council supports organ transplantation as a means of alleviating pain or saving life on the basis of the rules of the Shariah
  • Muslims may carry donor cards
  • the next of kin of a dead person, in the absence of a donor card or an expressed wish to donate their organs, may give permission to obtain organs from the body to save other people's lives
  • organ donation must be given freely without reward
  • trading in organs is prohibited.

 

]]>

document.body:
111-1January 2010 NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders newsletter

Welcome to the kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders specialist collection enewsletter for January 2010.

 

NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders is for busy health professionals, providing them with high quality information and keeping them up to date with the latest research and developments in this area. You can now join our mailing list to receive regular updates. Click here for the link.

 

 

***** Please help us to help you - if you are a renal healthcare professional or have an interest in kidney diseases, please complete our survey: http://www.surveymonkey.com/s/SHP9NTB *****

  

 

Links to:

  • New Kidney Diseases items
  • New Male Urogenital Disorders items

 

 RSS FEEDS 

 

You can receive news from the kidney diseases specialist collection from the RSS feeds we provide:

  1.  New Kidney Diseases Resources
  2.  New Male Urogenital Disorders Resources
  3.  Kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders in the news

Click through this link to find out more about RSS feeds.

 

JOURNALS

You can link through to the latest Tables of Contents from all the major kidney, transplant and urology journals from this page.

 

New resources added in December 2009

 

Chronic Kidney Disease

  • Antiviral therapy of hepatitis C in chronic kidney diseases: meta-analysis of controlled clinical trials. Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects (DARE) abstract.
  • Achieving Excellence in Kidney Care: Delivering the National Service Framework for Renal Services. Report published by the Department of Health.
  • Reduced level of consciousness from baclofen in people with low kidney function. Analysis by the National electronic Library for Medicines (05/01/10).
  • Chronic Kidney Disease: Systematic Reviews and Meta-analyses (2006-2009).

Acute kidney injury

  • Systematic review: sodium bicarbonate treatment regimens for the prevention of contrast-induced nephropathy. Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects (DARE) abstract.

  • Association between oral sodium phosphate bowel preparations and kidney injury: a systematic review and meta-analysis. Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects (DARE) abstract.

  • Systematic reviews and meta-analyses on Acute Kidney Injury (2006-2009).

Anaemia

  • Anaemia: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses (2006-2009).

Renovascular disease

  • Renal stenting for treatment of renal stenosis in patients with hypertension. CRD Health Technology Assessment Database abstract.

Diabetic nephropathy

  • Low-protein diet for diabetic nephropathy: a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials. Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects (DARE) abstract.
  • Diabetic Nephropathy: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses. (2006-2009).

Dialysis

  • Use of contra-indicated medications in dialysis patients undergoing PCI. Analysis by the National electronic Library for Medicines (09/12/09).
  • Continuous Renal Replacement Therapy: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses (2006-2009).
  • Dialysis: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses (2006-2009).

Transplantation

  • Commercialization of kidney transplants: a systematic review of outcomes in recipients and donors. Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects (DARE) abstract.
  • 'Risky donor' kidney transplants prove successful. Link to BBC news item. (07/12/09).
  • Kidney removal as day case surgery. Link to BBC news item (07.12.09).
  • Israeli organ donors to get transplant priority. Link to BBC news item. (17/12/09).
  • Wales seeks organ opt-out powers. Link to BBC news item. (18/12/09).
  • Live transplants hit 3,000 figure. Link to BBC news item. (22/12/09).
  • Preparing for life after death. Link to BBC Opinion item. (24/12/09).

Kidney Cancer

  • Percutaneous cryoablation for treatment of renal cell cancer. CRD Health Technology Assessment Database abstract.
  • Radiofrequency ablation for renal tumors. CRD Health Technology Assessment Database abstract.

Kidney stones

  • Modulith SLX Lithotripter (Storz Medical AG) for treatment of renal calculi. CRD Health Technology Assessment Database abstract.

 

Male Urogenital Disorders

Male Bladder Disorders

  • StatLock stabilization devices (Bard Medical) to reduce needlesticks and catheter-related infection. CRD Health Technology Assessment Database abstract.

Prostate Disorders

  • Potassium-titanyl-phosphate (KTP) laser photoselective vaporization prostatectomy (PVP) for benign prostatic hyperplasia (GreenLight PV; Laserscope). CRD Health Technology Assessment Database abstract.
  • Prostate saturation biopsy for diagnosis of prostate cancer. CRD Health Technology Assessment Database abstract.
  • Combined magnetic resonance imaging and magnetic resonance spectroscopy imaging in the diagnosis of prostate cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis. Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects (DARE) abstract.

  • Statin use and the risk of prostate cancer: a metaanalysis of 6 randomized clinical trials and 13 observational studies. Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects (DARE) abstract.

  • Latest systematic reviews on Surgery for prostate cancer.

  • Reclassification encourages men to play a more active role in their healthcare. News item from the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (03/12/09).

Penile Disorders

  • GMC criticises circumcision care. Link to BBC news item. (07/12/09).

Male urinary incontinence

  • Male lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS): guideline consultation. Link to NICE webpage for consultation.

Sexually Transmitted Infections

  • Assessment of the routine, occupation-based gonorrhea and syphilis screening program in Moscow, Russia: an analysis of sexually transmitted infection prevalence and cost-effectiveness. NHS Economic Evaluation Database (NEED) abstract.

 

 

**Subscribe to the NHS Evidence Eyes on Evidence Newsletter**


If you would like to receive Eyes on Evidence, the monthly e-bulletin from NHS Evidence, please sign up at http://www.evidence.nhs.uk/NewsletterSignup.aspx.


The bulletin will keep you updated with new and important evidence and key developments on the NHS Evidence portal.  It comes out on the second Wednesday of the month and can be sent to any e-mail address that you provide.

]]>

111-1January 2011 NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders newsletter

Welcome to the kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders specialist collection enewsletter for JANUARY 2011.

NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders is for busy health professionals, providing them with high quality information and keeping them up to date with the latest research and developments in this area. 

 

***If you subscribe to our JISCMAIL listing, you should have received an email about changes to the service and transfer of subscriber details to the new providers. If you DO NOT wish your details to be transferred, please make sure you let Eli Bastin know by 28th January - please use the Contact Us page to do so. If you do not opt out by this date, it will be assumed that you are happy to have your details transferred.***

Chronic Kidney Disease

  • Renal Tsar - Transition arrangements for the NHS. Dr Donal O'Donoghue  (23/12/10).

Diabetic nephropathy

  • Altered dietary salt intake for preventing and treating diabetic kidney disease. A new Cochrane systematic review.

Hypertension

  • The clinical and economic burden of nonadherence with antihypertensive and lipid-lowering therapy in hypertensive patients. A new item from the CRD NHS Economic Evaluation Database.
  • Hypertension in pregnancy - Clinical Knowledge Summaries.
  • Effect of cocoa products on blood pressure - systematic review and meta-analysis. A new item from the CRD Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.
  • Compliance safety and effectiveness of fixed-dose combinations of antihypertensive agents- a meta-analysis. A new item from the CRD Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.

Acute kidney injury

  • No new resources this month.

End-Stage Renal Disease

  • No new resources this month.

Renovascular diseases

  • No new resources this month.

Glomerulonephritis

Other renal conditions

Renal tract infections

  • No new resources this month.

Kidney stones

  • No new resources this month.

Renal vasculitis

  • No new resources this month.

Haemodialysis

Peritoneal Dialysis
 

  • European Medicines Agency recommends action plan to deal with possible presence of endotoxins in Baxter peritoneal dialysis solutions. National electronic Library for Medicines (20/12/10)

Transplantation

  • Clinical pharmacy services and solid organ transplantation - a literature review. A new item from the CRD Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.
  • Generic or branded mycophenolate - what strategy should the NHS adopt. National electronic Library for Medicines (17/12/10).

Kidney Cancer

  • No new resources this month.

 

Male Urogenital Disorders

  • Systematic review on Influence of obesity on the incidence and treatment of genitourinary malignancies. A new systematic review by Stewart and Freedland, published in Urologic Oncology.

Male Ureteric Disorders

Male Bladder Disorders

  • Photodynamic diagnosis in bladder cancer detection and treatment. A new item from the Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Bladder tumor antigen test. A new item from the Health Technology Assessment Database.

Prostate Disorders

  • Comparative evaluation of radiation treatments for clinically localized prostate cancer- an update. A new item from the Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • High intensity focused ultrasound. A new item from the Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Economic evaluation of population-based PSA screening for prostate cancer. A new item from the Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Health Agencies Update - Prostate Drug Warnings (23/12/10).
  • Is mitochondrial DNA the secret of prostate cancer? New Scientist article (21/12/10).

Penile Disorders

  • No new resources this month.

Urethral disorders

  • No new resources this month.

Urinary tract infections

  • Management of childhood urinary tract infections - an economic modeling study. A new item from the CRD NHS Economic Evaluation Database.

Testicular/Scrotal Disorders

Male Urinary Incontinence

  • Cost-effectiveness of sacral neuromodulation versus intravesical botulinum A toxin for treatment of refractory urge incontinence. A new item from the CRD NHS Economic Evaluation Database.

Sexually Transmitted Infections

  • 2010 Annual Evidence Update - Sexual Health- HIV AIDS - Behaviour change in high-risk populations - home page. National Library for Public Health

Fertility

  • No new resources this month.

document.title: Journal Update: January 2010
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders
document.topics: <![CDATA[ NEW RESEARCH,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.body:
111-1Journal Update: January 2010

Journal Update: January 2010

Abboud H, Henrich WL. Stage IV Chronic Kidney Disease. NEJM 362: 56-65 (2010) [Link to NEJM]


The Clinical Practice feature of the New England Journal of Medicine has reviewed the management and investigation of a patient with stage IV Chronic Kidney Disease.


The article summaries the relative incidence of CKD stage IV, causes and management, both in terms of reduction of progressive renal damage, and the complications of CKD that are common at this range of renal function.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Kidney Diseases and Male Urogenital Disorders]]>
document.title: Judaism and organ donation
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRANSPLANTATION,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.description: A guide to organ donation and the Jewish faith
document.body:
Extract from website

Most donated organs come from people who die from a severe brain injury and who receive treatment on a ventilator in an intensive care unit. The brain injury damages vital centres in the brain stem which are essential to maintain life. It is not the same as a 'coma' or 'persistive vegetative state'. No one can live once these centres have been destroyed. Tests are carried out to strict guidelines and show conclusively when this has happened.

In addition to the above, Jewish patients will require agreement from their Rabbinic authority that death as defined by Jewish law has definitely occurred.

Judaism and organ donation
In principle Judaism sanctions and encourages organ donation in order to save lives (pikuach nefesh).

This principle can sometimes override the strong objections to any unnecessary interference with the body after death, and the requirement for immediate burial of the complete body.

It is understandable that there will be worries about organ donation. At a time of stress and grief, linked to sudden unexpected illness and death, reaching a decision about donation can be difficult for a family. It is at this time that halachic guidance is so important.

Judaism insists that no organ may be removed from a donor until death - as defined in Jewish law - has definitely occurred. This can cause problems concerning heart, lung and similar transplants where time is of the essence.

Judaism insists that honour and respect are due to the dead (kavod hamet). After donation, the avoidance of unnecessary further interference with the body, and the need for immediate interment, are again of prime concern.

As all cases are different, Jewish law requires consultation with a competent Rabbinic authority before consent is granted.

These guidelines have been prepared in consultation with the Office of the Chief Rabbi
Please contact the Office of the Chief Rabbi, or another competent Halachic authority

 

 

]]>
document.relatedLinks: <a href="http://www.uktransplant.org.uk/ukt/how_to_become_a_donor/religious_perspectives/leaflets/judaism_and_organ_donation.jsp" title="Click here for webpage"/><a href="http://www.uktransplant.org.uk/ukt/newsroom/fact_sheets/religious_leaflets/judaism_and_organ_donation/judaism_and_organ_donation_v2.pdf" title="Click here for leaflet PDF"/>

111-1July 2009 NHS Evidence - kidney diseases newsletter

NHS Evidence - kidney diseases is for busy health professionals, providing them with high quality information and keeping them up to date with the latest research and developments in this area.

 

 

 

Images above and below were taken at the British Renal Society conference in Birmingham, 1-3rd June 2009 and show the NHS Evidence - kidney diseases stand.

 

 RSS FEEDS 

 

You can receive news from the kidney diseases specialist collection from the RSS feeds we provide:

  1.  New Resources added to NHS Evidence - kidney diseases
  2.  Kidney diseases in the news

Click through this link to find out more about RSS feeds.

 

JOURNALS

You can link through to the latest Tables of Contents from all the major kidney journals from this page.

 

New resources added in June 2009

Chronic Kidney  Disease

  • Which bowel cleansing solutions are suitable for use in people with renal impairment? A summary by the National electronic Library for Medicines (04/06/09) with a link to the Word document.
  • Map of Medicine use cuts poor referrals - News item from eHealth Insider about the impact of Map of Medicine use by primary care practitioners on chronic kidney disease referrals. (08/06/09)
  • Meta-analysis: intradermal vs. intramuscular vaccination against hepatitis B virus in patients with chronic kidney disease. A DARE abstract (April 2009)
  • Sevelamer carbonate (Renvela) approved in EU for chronic kidney disease. A summary by the National electronic Library for Medicines (15/06/09).
  • Healthcare workforce portal: Renal. A specialist website from the Skills for Health - Workforce Projects Team.
  • Systematic review: High target haemoglobin levels do not improve quality of life for patients with chronic kidney disease?  A summary by the National electronic Library for Medicines (23/06/09).
  • NSF for Renal Services Update - June 2009 - published by the Department of Health/ Dr Donal O'Donoghue.
  • New GMS Contract QOF Implementation - Dataset And Business Rules - Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD). The business rules for the new CKD domain of the Quality and Outcomes Framework provide the definition and codes for ckd. Published 1st July.
  • Review: Anaemia, diabetes, and chronic kidney disease. A summary by the National electronic Library for Medicines (02/07/09).

Complications of kidney disease

  • Cheng J, Zhang X et al. (2009) Efficacy and Safety of Glucocorticoids Therapy for IgA Nephropathy: A Meta-Analysis of Randomized Controlled Trials. American Journal of Nephrology. 2009, 30 (4); 315-322.

Acute renal failure

  • Acute kidney injury: adding insult to injury. NCEPOD Report (11 June 2009).

Renovascular diseases

  • Meta-analysis: terlipressin therapy for the hepatorenal syndrome (DARE abstract - June 2009)

 

Renal tract infections

  • Short- versus long-course antibiotic therapy for acute pyelonephritis in adolescents and adults: a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials (DARE abstract - June 2009)
  • BMJ Practice: Rational testing - assessing candiduria in a critically ill patient. A summary by the National electronic Library for Medicines (19/06/09).

Kidney and bladder stones

  • Diagnostic performance of low-dose CT for the detection of urolithiasis: a meta-analysis (DARE abstract - June 2009)
  • The effect of shock wave rate on the outcome of shock wave lithotripsy: a meta-analysis (DARE abstract- June 2009)

Haemodialysis

  • Antimicrobial lock solutions for the prevention of infections associated with intravascular catheters in patients undergoing hemodialysis: systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized, controlled trials (DARE abstract - June 2009)
  • GUIDELINE: Standards and recommendations for the provision of renal replacement therapy on intensive care units in the United Kingdom. Guidance from the Intensive Care Society, published January 2009.

Peritoneal dialysis

  • Meta-analysis: peritoneal membrane transport, mortality, and technique failure in peritoneal dialysis (DARE - June 2009)

Transplantation

  • Cost-effectiveness of colorectal cancer screening in renal transplant recipients (NEED - June 2009)
  • 3 June 2009 - Progress towards pig transplants: An NHS Choices Behind the Headlines story.
  • Prograf (tacrolimus) 5mg/ml Concentrate for Solution for Infusion - Revised SPC. A summary by the National electronic Library for Medicines (21/06/09).

Renal tract cancer

  • Kidney cancer: Treatment and Disease management: Biological Therapy - The cancer specialist collection have added the latest systematic reviews on this topic to the page.
  • Final results from Phase III trial comparing sunitinib and interferon-alfa in first-line treatment of metastatic renal cell carcinoma. A summary by the National electronic Library for Medicines (03/06/09).

document.body:
111-1July 2010 NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders newsletter

Welcome to the kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders specialist collection enewsletter for JULY 2010.

NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders is for busy health professionals, providing them with high quality information and keeping them up to date with the latest research and developments in this area. You can now join our mailing list to receive regular updates. Click here for the link.

 

Links to:

  • New Kidney Diseases items
  • New Male Urogenital Disorders items

 

 

NEW KIDNEY DISEASES MINI TOPIC REVIEWS:

  • The most recent mini topic review is by Michael Reschen MB MRCP(UK) and Christopher G Winearls MB (Cape Town), D.Phil(Oxon) FRCP (London): The TREAT Trial (June 2010).
  • An introductory article by Edward Sharples on Anaemia Management in CKD Patients is also now available on the specialist collection: Anaemia Management in CKD Patients - a mini-review (June 2010).
  • See also the latest mini topic review published by the Surgery, anaesthesia, perioperative and critical care specialist collection: Cardiac surgery-associated acute kidney injury, by Drs Amit Srivastava and Stephen T Webb (June 2010).

NEW UROLOGY MINI TOPIC REVIEWS:

  • Pete Acher and Alastair Henderson have written a mini topic review on Holmium laser surgery for benign prostatic enlargement (June 2010).

 

Do you use medicines information? Click here to take part in a short survey and tell us your views:

http://surveys.viewscount.com/vc/medicalinformationsurvey

 

 RSS FEEDS 

 

You can receive news from the kidney diseases specialist collection from the RSS feeds we provide:

  1.  New Kidney Diseases Resources
  2.  New Male Urogenital Disorders Resources
  3.  Kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders in the news

Click through this link to find out more about RSS feeds.

 

JOURNALS

You can link through to the latest Tables of Contents from all the major kidney, transplant and urology journals from this page.

 

Resources added in June 2010

 

Chronic Kidney Disease

  • Wearable artificial kidney (WAK): Portable dialysis for patients with chronic kidney disease. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Association of estimated glomerular filtration rate and albuminuria with all-cause and cardiovascular mortality in general population cohorts: a collaborative meta-analysis. A new abstract from the Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.
  • New introductory article and guest editorial on Anaemia Management in CKD Patients
  • Allopurinol may slow progression of renal disease and reduce cardiovascular risk in chronic kidney disease. Published 21/06/10 by the National electronic Library for Medicines.


Acute kidney injury

  • Nephrotoxicity of iso-osmolar iodixanol compared with nonionic low-osmolar contrast media: meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials. A new abstract from the Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.
  • Utility of urine myoglobin for the prediction of acute renal failure in patients with suspected rhabdomyolysis: a systematic review. A new abstract from the Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.
  • Mini topic review on Cardiac surgery-associated acute kidney injury.

Polycystic kidney disease

  • Everolimus in Patients with Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease. A new RCT published in the NEJM.
  • Sirolimus and Kidney Growth in Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease. New RCT published in NEJM.

Kidney stones

  • Diet, fluid, or supplements for secondary prevention of nephrolithiasis: a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized trials. A new abstract from the Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.

Renal vasculitis

  • Systematic review on Interventions for renal vasculitis in adults by Walters GD, Willis NS, Craig JC, published in BMC Nephrology.

Dialysis

  • The cost-effectiveness of increasing kidney transplantation and home-based dialysis. A new abstract from the NHS Economic Evaluation Database.
  • Wearable artificial kidney (WAK): Portable dialysis for patients with chronic kidney disease. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Ultrasound monitoring to detect access stenosis in hemodialysis patients: a systematic review. A new abstract from the Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.
  • Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers in peritoneal dialysis: systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials. A new abstract from the Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.
  • A Randomized Controlled Trial of Early versus Late Initiation of Dialysis. A new RCT published by the NEJM.


Transplantation

  • The cost-effectiveness of increasing kidney transplantation and home-based dialysis. A new abstract from the NHS Economic Evaluation Database.
  • LifePort kidney transporter: Portable donor kidney transporter/ perfuser. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Belatacept for prophylaxis of organ rejection in renal transplantation. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Steroid avoidance or withdrawal after renal transplantation increases the risk of acute rejection but decreases cardiovascular risk: a meta-analysis. A new abstract from the Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.

Kidney Cancer

  • Pazopanib (GW786034) for advanced and/or metastatic renal cell carcinoma - first/second line. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Everolimus: efficiency, efficacy and safety. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Everolimus for advanced and/or metastatic renal cell carcinoma - second line. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.

 

Male Urogenital Disorders

Male Ureteric Disorders

  • Cost-effectiveness of treating ureteral stones in a Taipei city hospital: shock wave lithotripsy versus ureteroscopy plus lithoclast. A new abstract from the NHS Economic Evaluation Database.

Male Bladder Disorders

  • NMP22 BladderChek Diagnostic test for bladder cancer: update. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Treatment success for overactive bladder with urinary urge incontinence refractory to oral antimuscarinics: a review of published evidence. A new abstract from the Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.
  • OTC Tamsulosin - 400 micrograms: practice guidance. Published March 2010.

Prostate Disorders

  • Cost-effectiveness of MR lymphography for the detection of lymph node metastases in patients with prostate cancer. A new abstract from the NHS Economic Evaluation Database.
  • Dutasteride (Avodart) for prevention of prostate cancer. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Da Vinci robotic surgical system for gynecologic and urologic oncology. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • A systematic review of physical activity in prostate cancer survivors: outcomes, prevalence, and determinants. A new abstract from the Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.

Penile Disorders

  • Haematospermia. New guidance from Clinical Knowledge Summaries.
  • Haematospermia: Assessment of haematospermia. New guidance from Clinical Knowledge Summaries.
  • Haematospermia: Haematospermia. New guidance from Clinical Knowledge Summaries.
  • Acupuncture for treating erectile dysfunction: a systematic review. A new abstract from the Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.

Urinary tract infection

  • Cost-effectiveness of sacral neuromodulation versus intravesical botulinum A toxin for treatment of refractory urge incontinence. A new abstract from the NHS Economic Evaluation Database.

Testicular/Scrotal Disorders

  • A decision analysis of treatments for nonobstructive azoospermia associated with varicocele. A new abstract from the NHS Economic Evaluation Database.
  • 2010 United Kingdom national guideline for the management of epididymo-orchitis. New guideline, published May 2010, replaces previous guidance of January 2001. Royal Pharmaceutical Society


Sexually Transmitted Infections

  • Herpes simplex - genital: Diagnosis of herpes simplex - genital. New guidance from Clinical Knowledge Summaries.
  • Preventing sexually transmitted infections among incarcerated men who have sex with men: a cost-effectiveness analysis. A new abstract from the NHS Economic Evaluation Database.
  • Rapid urine test for Chlamydia trachomatis. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Sexual health toolkit. New guideline, published March 2010

 

 

]]>

NHS Economic Evaluation Database

Also...

Evidence in the News

  • Progress towards pig transplants - NHS Choices Behind the Headlines review 03/06/09  
  • Final results from Phase III trial comparing sunitinib and interferon-alfa in first-line treatment of metastatic renal cell carcinoma - from NeLM news service 03/06/09
  • Which bowel cleansing solutions are suitable for use in people with renal impairment? - from NeLM news service 04/06/0/9


Reference materials

  • Bladder and kidneys - BMJ Best Treatments resources
  • NHS Kidney Care Matters Online - June newsletter
  • Specialised Renal Services (Adult): Definition No. 11 - NHS National Specialised Commissioning Group (Published 19 May 2009)
  • Programme budgeting in Kidney Care - from the Renal Tsar's blog (28/05/09)

 

Patient Information

  • Kidney transplant: Tony's story - video from NHS Choices
  • Urinary tract infections - video from NHS Choices

document.body:
111-1June 2010 NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders newsletter

Welcome to the kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders specialist collection enewsletter for JUNE 2010.

NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders is for busy health professionals, providing them with high quality information and keeping them up to date with the latest research and developments in this area. You can now join our mailing list to receive regular updates. Click here for the link.

 

Links to:

  • New Kidney Diseases items
  • New Male Urogenital Disorders items

 

 

On Monday 24th May, the specialist collection launched the third Annual Evidence Update on Proteinuria and eGFR:

The 2010 update on the topics of eGFR and proteinuria focuses on the new evidence underpinning the importance of microalbuminuria and proteinuria as a marker of renal and cardiovascular disease and progression. Two commentaries highlight the new evidence for pre-eclampsia as a risk factor for CKD, and the ongoing debates around eGFR, old age and CKD classifications.

Link to 2010 AEU on Proteinuria and eGFR contents page

 

 

 

 RSS FEEDS 

 

You can receive news from the kidney diseases specialist collection from the RSS feeds we provide:

  1.  New Kidney Diseases Resources
  2.  New Male Urogenital Disorders Resources
  3.  Kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders in the news

Click through this link to find out more about RSS feeds.

 

JOURNALS

You can link through to the latest Tables of Contents from all the major kidney, transplant and urology journals from this page.

 

Resources added in May 2010

 

Chronic Kidney Disease

  • 2010 Annual Evidence Update on Proteinuria and eGFR - link to contents page
  • Implantable cardioverter defibrillator therapy in chronic kidney disease: a meta-analysis. A new abstract from the Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.

  • Biofeedback for the treatment of hypertension. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.


Acute kidney injury

  • Nothing this month.

Diabetic nephropathy

  • Prostaglandin E1 for preventing the progression of diabetic kidney disease. New Cochrane systematic review.

  • Tongxinluo capsule for diabetic kidney disease: a systematic review. A new abstract from the Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.

  • Pancreas-after-kidney (PAK) transplantation in diabetic patients. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Simultaneous pancreas-kidney (SPK) transplantation in diabetic patients. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.

Other kidney conditions - SLE and inherited

  • Belimumab (Benlysta) for active systemic lupus erythematosus. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Everolimus for autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease with renal impairment. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.

Renal tract infections

  • Pyelonephritis - acute: Diagnosis of acute pyelonephritis. New guidance from Clinical Knowledge Summaries.

Dialysis

  • Heparin versus citrate for anticoagulation in critically ill patients treated with continuous renal replacement therapy. A new abstract from the Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.
  • Home hemodialysis. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.

Transplantation

  • Budget impact analysis for renal transplantation. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Everolimus (Certican) for prophylaxis of organ rejection in renal or cardiac transplantation. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Guidelines for the detection and characterisation of clinically relevant antibodies in allotransplantation. Published 15 March 2010 by the British Transplantation Society.

 

Kidney Cancer

  • Bevacizumab, sorafenib tosylate, sunitinib and temsirolimus for renal cell carcinoma: a systematic review and economic evaluation. A new abstract from the Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.
  • Positron emission tomography for nine cancers (bladder, brain, cervical, kidney, ovarian, pancreatic, prostate, small cell lung, testicular). A new abstract from the Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.
  • Everolimus (Afinitor) for advanced/metastatic kidney cancer. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Off-label uses of Sorafenib and Sunitinib. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.

 

 

Male Urogenital Disorders

  • NEW NICE GUIDELINE: Lower urinary tract symptoms: the management of lower urinary tract symptoms in men.
  • Guidelines on conservative treatment of non-neurogenic male LUTS. Published April 2010 by the European Association of Urology.

Male Bladder Disorders

  • Silver-coated urinary catheters for prevention of urinary tract infections. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Ureteral bulking agents for vesicoureteral reflux disease. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.

Prostate Disorders

  • Prostatitis - acute: Diagnosis of acute prostatitis. New guidance from Clinical Knowledge Summaries.
  • Prostatitis - chronic: Diagnosis of chronic prostatitis. New guidance from Clinical Knowledge Summaries.
  • Bipolar versus monopolar transurethral resection of the prostate: a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials. A new abstract from the Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.
  • Tamsulosin versus terazosin for benign prostatic hyperplasia: a systematic review. A new abstract from the Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.
  • Adjuvant radiotherapy following radical prostatectomy for pathologic T3 or margin-positive prostate cancer: guideline recommendations. A new abstract from the Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.
  • Comparative effectiveness of therapies for clinically localized prostate cancer. A new abstract from the Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.
  • The use of bisphosphonates in men with hormone-refractory prostate cancer. A new abstract from the Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.
  • Cabazitaxel (XRP-6258) for hormone refractory, metastatic prostate cancer - second line after docetaxel. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Conformal and intensity-modulated radiation therapy for prostate cancer. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Cryoablation for prostate cancer. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Holmium laser enucleation of benign prostatic hyperplasia. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Intensity modulated radiotherapy for the treatment of prostate cancer: a systematic review and economic evaluation. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Laparoscopic radical prostatectomy. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Laser treatment for benign prostatic hyperplasia: defining assessment indicators. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Management options for low-risk prostate cancer: a report on comparative effectiveness and value. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Prostate trials office (PROTO): co-ordinating trials of new technologies in the treatment of BPH. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Proton beam therapy for prostate cancer. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Robotic-assisted prostatectomy. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Saw palmetto for benign prostatic hyperplasia. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Silodosin for benign prostatic hyperplasia. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Simultaneous irradiation (ProstRcision) for localized prostate cancer. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Special report: recent developments in prostate cancer genetics and genetic testing. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Symptomatic benign prostatic obstruction (BPO). A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • The ProtecT trial - evaluating the effectiveness of treatments for clinically localised prostate cancer. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.

Penile Disorders

  • Male circumcision at different ages in Rwanda: a cost-effectiveness study. A new abstract from the NHS Economic Evaluation Database.

Urinary tract infection

  • The Diagnosis of Urinary Tract infection in Young children (DUTY) study. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • The PLUTO Trial: Percutaneous shunting in Lower Urinary Tract Obstruction. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.

Testicular/Scrotal Disorders

  • Varicocele: Diagnosis of varicocele. New guidance from Clinical Knowledge Summaries.
  • Testosterone and depression: systematic review and meta-analysis. A new abstract from the Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects.

Urinary incontinence

  • Behavioural interventions for urinary incontinence in community-dwelling seniors: an evidence-based analysis. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Pelvic floor electrical stimulation for the treatment of urinary incontinence. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.

Sexually Transmitted Infections

  • Gonorrhoea: Diagnosis of gonorrhoea. New guidance from Clinical Knowledge Summaries.
  • Congenital syphilis: an economic evaluation of a prevention program in China. A new abstract from the NHS Economic Evaluation Database.
  • Clinical and cost-effectiveness of technologies for testing and treating sexual partners of people with sexually transmitted infections: Evidence synthesis and mathematical modelling study. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Rapid antibody testing for HIV. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • Systematic review of the clinical and cost-effectiveness of rapid point-of-care tests for the detection of genital Chlamydia infection in women and men. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.
  • The effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of behavioural interventions for the prevention of sexually transmitted infections in young people aged 13-19: a systematic review and economic evaluation. A new item from the CRD Health Technology Assessment Database.

Fertility

  • Nothing this month.

 

 

 

**Subscribe to the NHS Evidence Eyes on Evidence Newsletter**


If you would like to receive Eyes on Evidence, the monthly e-bulletin from NHS Evidence, please sign up at http://www.evidence.nhs.uk/NewsletterSignup.aspx.


The bulletin will keep you updated with new and important evidence and key developments on the NHS Evidence portal.  It comes out on the second Wednesday of the month and can be sent to any e-mail address that you provide.

document.title: KDIGO Clinical Practice Guideline for the Care of Kidney Transplant Recipients
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRANSPLANT OPERATION,IMMUNOSUPPRESSIVE DRUGS,UK TRANSPLANT,TRANSPLANT CENTRES,PREVENTION OF COMPLICATIONS,ASSESSMENT/SELECTION,TRANSPLANTATION,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.description: This Clinical Practice Guideline document is based upon the best information available as of March 2009. It is designed to provide information and assist decisionmaking. It is not intended to define a standard of care, and should not be construed as one, nor should it be interpreted as prescribing an exclusive course of management.
document.body:
This Clinical Practice Guideline document is based upon the best information available as of March 2009. It is designed to provide information and assist decisionmaking. It is not intended to define a standard of care, and should not be construed as one, nor should it be interpreted as prescribing an exclusive course of management.

document.title: Kidney and bladder stones: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders
document.topics: <![CDATA[ KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY AND BLADDER STONES,MALE BLADDER DISORDERS,BLADDER STONES,MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.body:
111-1Kidney and bladder stones: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses

NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders has identified the following resources relevant to this topic area. We perform systematic searches to identify up-to-date, high quality evidence for a given topic. View our content development strategy for more information.

Users should note that we have not performed an in-depth appraisal for each reference but have applied rigorous methods to select them.  Where pre-appraisals exist, we link to them.   We recommend that a full appraisal is completed using the appropriate check-list provided by the Centre for Evidence-Based Medicine.  We welcome feedback about resources that we identify, do contact us if you would like to comment.

 

References:

 

2010

  • Borges, C.F., Fregonesi, A., Silva, D.C., Sasse, A.D. (2010) "Systematic review and meta-analysis of nephrostomy placement versus tubeless percutaneous nephrolithotomy." J Endourol. Oct 19 [Epub ahead of print] [Link to PubMed abstract]
  • Castagnetti, M. and W. Rigamonti (2010). "Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy for the treatment of urinary stones in children." Archivio Italiano di Urologia, Andrologia 82(1): 49-50. [Link to PubMed abstract]

  • Skolarikos, A., M. P. Laguna, et al. (2010). "The role for active monitoring in urinary stones: A systematic review." Journal of Endourology 24(6): 923-930. [Link to PubMed abstract]
  • Skolarikos, A., H. Mitsogiannis, et al. (2010). "Indications, prediction of success and methods to improve outcome of shock wave lithotripsy of renal and upper ureteral calculi." Archivio Italiano di Urologia, Andrologia 82(1): 56-63. [Link to PubMed abstract]
  • Wang, K. J., L. H. Jiang, et al. (2010). "Urologist versus radiologist for percutaneous nephrolithotomy access under fluoroscopic guidance: A systematic review." European Urology, Supplements 9(2). [No PubMed abstract available]

2009

document.description: The kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders specialist collection team have performed systematic searches to identify up-to-date, high quality evidence for a given topic.
document.body:
111-1Kidney Diseases: Systematic Reviews and Meta-analyses

The specialist collection team have performed systematic searches to identify up-to-date, high quality evidence for a given topic.

 

We use the Cochrane Collaboration's definition of a systematic review when sifting and reviewing references:


"A review of a clearly formulated question that uses systematic and explicit methods to identify, select, and critically appraise relevant research, and to collect and analyse data from the studies that are included in the review. Statistical methods (meta-analysis) may or may not be used to analyse and summarise the results of the included studies."

Link to The Cochrane Collaboration Glossary

document.title: Legal issues relevant to non-heartbeating organ donation
document.topics: <![CDATA[ EMERGENCY CARE,HEALTH MANAGEMENT,POLICY,ETHICS AND STANDARDS,TISSUE DONATION,CONSENT,CLINICAL LIBRARY,ORGANISATIONAL AND OTHER ISSUES,SURGERY,SURGERY,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,TRANSPLANTATION,TRANSPLANT OPERATION,ASSESSMENT/SELECTION,UK TRANSPLANT,TRANSPLANT CENTRES,CLINICAL TOPICS,CRITICAL CARE,KIDNEY DISEASES,CAPACITY,TRANSPLANTATION]]>
document.description: The Department of Health's view of the legal position in relation to the action that can be lawfully taken prior to death to support non-heartbeating donation, produced in response to Recommendation 3 of the Organ Donation Taskforce Report which states that 'urgent attention is required to resolve outstanding legal, ethical and professional issues in order to ensure that all clinicians are supported and are able to work within a clear and unambiguous framework of good practice.' The intention is that those working in this area will be able to use it to draw up more detailed guidance to support clinical practice. This guidance is only applicable in England and Wales.
document.body: <![CDATA[ The Department of Health's view of the legal position in relation to the action that can be lawfully taken prior to death to support non-heartbeating donation, produced in response to Recommendation 3 of the Organ Donation Taskforce Report which states that 'urgent attention is required to resolve outstanding legal, ethical and professional issues in order to ensure that all clinicians are supported and are able to work within a clear and unambiguous framework of good practice.' The intention is that those working in this area will be able to use it to draw up more detailed guidance to support clinical practice. This guidance is only applicable in England and Wales.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Kidney Diseases and Male Urogenital Disorders]]>
document.title: Leicester Renal Unit, Leicester General Hospital
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRANSPLANTATION,TRANSPLANT CENTRES,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.description: Contact details and background information
document.body:
Extract from webpage

Leicester General Hospital (LGH) is part of the University Hospitals of Leicester NHS Trust and provides a specialist renal service for the total population Leicestershire, Lincolnshire and Northamptonshire as well as a proportion of the population of Cambridgeshire. The total population served is approximately 2.3 million.

Transplantation
An active live donor and cadaver (including non-heart beating donor) transplant service is led by Professor M Nicholson. The 14-bedded Transplant Ward cares for both donors and recipients.


The Live Donor Service has a dedicated Senior Nursing team who manage the service and prepares both the donor and patient for transplant. Laparascopic Donor nephrectomy is available. On average, 25 live donor transplants are undertaken each year. This is an expanding service. The cadaver transplant service has 4wte donor nurses and has recently combined rotas with the Trent Network to manage resources more effectively. Approximately 25 cadaver transplants are performed each year.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Kidney Diseases and Male Urogenital Disorders]]>
document.title: Let's talk renal rubbish
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HAEMODIALYSIS,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY DISEASES,DIALYSIS]]>
document.description: A podcast by Mary Thomson
document.body:
Mary Thomson has worked in renal nursing for almost 20 years, but in 2005-2008 she took a break and worked in the community, developing a programme for children aged 7-11 yrs to encourage active citizenship. A favourite activity was a visit to the local landfill site, where they saw composting & recycling on a huge scale.

Returning to the renal unit, Mary was taken aback by the lack of facilitates for segregating waste - 2 different coloured bags - take your pick! The plastic dialysate bottles being put to landfill and not even crushed! She decided to survey colleagues, asking about their recycling practices at home and aiming to find out "what happens to us when we come through the double doors to work"?

 

Download audio file (MP3)

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Kidney Diseases and Male Urogenital Disorders]]>
document.title: Lupus Nephritis:case presentation
document.publisher: ERA-EDTA in collaboration with Renal Pathology Society
document.topics: <![CDATA[ OTHER CONDITIONS - ADULTS,SLE-RELATED,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.description: Case presentation from CME Course on Renal Pathology
document.body:
5 questions with multiple choice answers

1. What is the probability of have a focal or diffuse proliferative lupus nephritis at renal biopsy (class III or ClassIV WHO) in a patient with urinary abnormalities without nephrotic syndrome or renal insufficiency?

2. What would you do with therapy when a patient with diffuse proliferative lupus nephritis enters complete clinical remission?  

3. The literature being controversial as regards the significance of anti-DNA antibodies, what could be the most useful serological test to confirm the clinical diagnosis of a renal flare?

4. What is the rate of transformation of diffuse proliferative lupus nephritis (Class IV) into membranous lupus nephritis (Class V) ?

5. What therapy would you administer to a patient with lupus nephritis and positive antiphospholipid antibodies after a serious thrombotic event?

 

 

]]>

document.description: NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders has identified the following resources relevant to this topic area. We perform systematic searches to identify up-to-date, high quality evidence for a given topic.
document.body:
111-1Male Urogenital Disorders: Systematic Reviews and Meta-analyses

The specialist collection team have performed systematic searches to identify up-to-date, high quality evidence for a given topic.

 

We use the Cochrane Collaboration's definition of a systematic review when sifting and reviewing references:


"A review of a clearly formulated question that uses systematic and explicit methods to identify, select, and critically appraise relevant research, and to collect and analyse data from the studies that are included in the review. Statistical methods (meta-analysis) may or may not be used to analyse and summarise the results of the included studies."

Link to The Cochrane Collaboration Glossary

document.title: Managing anaemia in renal failure
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLICATIONS OF KIDNEY DISEASE,ANAEMIA,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.description: Review of use of Erythropoiesis-stimulating Agents (ESAs) and comments on the European Best Practice Guidelines published in May 2004
document.body:
Extract from review

Over the past decade, effective management [of anaemia in CKD] has become possible using safer intravenous iron preparations and genetically engineered erythropoiesis-stimulating agents  (ESAs). This CPD article reviews the situation with regard to the latest European Best Practice Guideline., and the Renal Association standards.

]]>

document.body:
111-1March 2010 NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders newsletter

Welcome to the kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders specialist collection enewsletter for MARCH 2010.

NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders is for busy health professionals, providing them with high quality information and keeping them up to date with the latest research and developments in this area. You can now join our mailing list to receive regular updates. Click here for the link.

 

 

***** Quick survey open to library users to find out what information you need and what you think of our Annual Evidence Updates and Treatment Uncertainties: http://www.surveymonkey.com/s/GGMQ5T8 *****

 

Links to:

  • New Kidney Diseases items
  • New Male Urogenital Disorders items

 

 RSS FEEDS 

 

You can receive news from the kidney diseases specialist collection from the RSS feeds we provide:

  1.  New Kidney Diseases Resources
  2.  New Male Urogenital Disorders Resources
  3.  Kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders in the news

Click through this link to find out more about RSS feeds.

 

JOURNALS

You can link through to the latest Tables of Contents from all the major kidney, transplant and urology journals from this page.

 

Resources added in February 2010

 

Chronic Kidney Disease

  • Effect of medication dosing frequency on adherence in chronic diseases. A DARE Abstract.
  • E-health self-care interventions for persons with chronic illnesses: review and future directions. A DARE abstract.
  • Does adding a CCB rather than diuretic to an ACE-inhibitor increase renal protection? From the National electronic Library for Medicines (18/02/10)


Acute kidney injury

  • High-dose N-acetylcysteine for the prevention of contrast-induced nephropathy. A DARE abstract.
  • Clinical decision support system to determine quality of antimicrobial dosing in ICU patients with renal insufficiency. From the National electronic Library for Medicines (26/02/10).

Hypertension

  • No new items this month.

Renovascular disease

  • Guest editorial: Implications of the ASTRAL (Angioplasty and Stenting for Renal Artery Lesions) trial for current management of atherosclerotic renovascular disease (ARVD). By Professor Philip A Kalra. (09/02/10)

Diabetic nephropathy

  • NHS Diabetes commissioning resource. Published 1 March 2010.

Glomerulonephritis

  • Mycophenolate mofetil treatment for IgA nephropathy: a meta-analysis. A DARE abstract.

Dialysis

  • A systematic review of continuous renal replacement therapy and intermittent haemodialysis in management of patients with acute renal failure. A DARE abstract.
  • NHS Kidney Care Home Haemodialysis resources.

Transplantation

  • The effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of methods of storing donated kidneys from deceased donors: a systematic review and economic evaluation. A Health Technology Assessment abstract.
  • Horizon scanning: Belatacept as immunosuppression after kidney transplant. From the National electronic Library for Medicines (22/02/10).
  • Cohort study: Effect of reduced immunosuppression after kidney transplant failure on risk of cancer. From the National electronic Library for Medicines (12/02/10).

Kidney Cancer

  • European CHMP issues positive opinion on marketing authorisation application for pazopanib (Votrient®) as treatment of advanced renal cell carcinoma. From the National electronic Library for Medicines (19/02/10).

Kidney stones

  • Kidney and bladder stones: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses (Updated February 2010).

 

Male Urogenital Disorders

Male Bladder Disorders

  • SMC accepts trospium film-coated tablets (Flotros®) for overactive bladder. From the National electronic Library for Medicines (08/02/10).

Prostate Disorders

  • Updated systematic reviews and meta-analyses: Benign Prostate Enlargement (February 2010).

Penile Disorders

  • Red ginseng for treating erectile dysfunction: a systematic review. A DARE abstract.
  • Circumcision: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses (New for February 2010).
  • Hypospadias: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses (Updated February 2010).

Testicular/Scrotal Disorders

  • No new items this month.

Male Urinary Incontinence

  • 2010 Annual Evidence Update on Male Urinary Incontinence - link to contents page

Urinary tract infection - Clinical Knowledge Summaries

  • Urinary tract infection (lower) – men
  • Urinary tract infection (lower) - men: Lower urinary tract infection in men
  • Urinary tract infection (lower) - men: Urinary tract infection in men with an indwelling catheter

Sexually Transmitted Infections

  • Cost-effectiveness of genotypic antiretroviral resistance testing in HIV-infected patients with treatment failure. An abstract from the NHS Economic Evaluation Database.

 

Fertility

  • Infertility: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses (Updated February 2010).

 

 

 

**Subscribe to the NHS Evidence Eyes on Evidence Newsletter**


If you would like to receive Eyes on Evidence, the monthly e-bulletin from NHS Evidence, please sign up at http://www.evidence.nhs.uk/NewsletterSignup.aspx.


The bulletin will keep you updated with new and important evidence and key developments on the NHS Evidence portal.  It comes out on the second Wednesday of the month and can be sent to any e-mail address that you provide.

]]>

document.body:
111-1March 2011 NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders newsletter

Welcome to the last kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders specialist collection enewsletter for MARCH 2011.

NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders is for busy health professionals, providing them with high quality information and keeping them up to date with the latest research and developments in this area. 

 

New this month:

  • Changes to the specialist collections
  • Renal Hot Topics
  • New Mini Topic Review on Kidney Stones
  • 2011 Annual Evidence Update on Prostate Cancer

 

Links to:

  • New Kidney Diseases items
  • New Male Urogenital Disorders items

 

   

Changes to the Specialist Collections

A new specialist evidence service to replace the kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders specialist collection.

As you know, this specialist collection provides access to specialised information on behalf of NICE (NHS Evidence). 

From May 2011, NICE (NHS Evidence) will launch a new specialist evidence service to replace the kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders specialist collection and the other 29 Specialist Collections.

The new service will be easy to search and provide access to a much wider choice of quality specialist evidence content.

Users will be able to browse new clinical and public health topic pages – developed by experts - which will bring together the latest guidelines, high quality patient information, ongoing trials and other selected information including access to NICE pathways. NICE Pathways will allow users to easily visualise and browse associated NICE products online, guided through supporting documents making NICE guidance easier to navigate.


Newsletters
In view of the change to the new service this newsletter for March 2011 will be the last one. 

NHS Evidence will continue to identify significant new evidence and will disseminate this quality assured, significant, new evidence via its monthly Eyes on Evidence bulletin.

The bulletin will provide a link to new, significant evidence for that month. . Later in the year a personalised update function will be introduced which will allow you to specify exactly what you wish to be notified about.

If you have already agreed to pass on your contact details to NICE you will receive the Eyes on Evidence bulletin.

OTHER CHANGES

Evidence Updates

Evidence Updates will continue to be produced by NHS Evidence to raise awareness of new evidence and will reflect prioritised topics, where there are accredited guidelines.

There will be some core, consistent topics, but new topics may be added on an annual basis to increase the coverage of accredited guideline topics over time.

Evidence Updates themselves will be available by searching on the relevant topic term on NHS Evidence, or by accessing the guideline panel in the new redesigned site, or through features in Eyes on Evidence. 

Forthcoming Evidence Updates will be advertised on  lis-medical, lis-nursing, Corecontent, Nelm, Chain, CKS and Wiley and on a dedicated web page on NHS Evidence.  They will also continue to be submitted as journal articles for publication by NICE with input from the Clinical Leads.

Stakeholder Engagement: Evidence Associates
NICE will continue to engage with specialist community stakeholders through a new network of Evidence Associates.

If you want to find out more about how to become an  Evidence Associate  then please contact Frances Abebreseh at NICE by emailing: frances.abebreseh@nice.org.uk

Evidence Associates will be invited to take part in the Evidence Update process, answering questions or contributing to the horizon scanning process of identifying new significant evidence. Evidence Associates may also want to be involved in the production or co-authoring of feature articles for the Eyes on Evidence bulletin or press articles. 


Specialist Collections web pages (on www.library.nhs.uk)
From May 2011 the kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders’s web pages will no longer exist as the specialist resources for kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders will be accessible via the redesigned NHS Evidence site.  If you have added these pages to your bookmarks and favourites then these links will still work for a short period until early May 2011 then but they will then be redirected to the main NHS Evidence site.

UK DUETS
UK DUETS will continue to be available via a dedicated web page on NHS Evidence. Uncertainty records will be available in the search results as well as under the On-going Research panel of the future topic pages. Work is on-going with users of UK DUETS and the NICE Research Recommendations database to build an integrated approach to the capture of Research Uncertainties.

Who to contact
From April 2011, if you have queries you can contact NHS Evidence directly by emailing contactus@evidence.nhs.uk or calling 0845 003 77 44.

 

MARCH 2011: RENAL HOT TOPICS

 

 

New England Journal of Medicine

  • Inglehart JK. (2011) "Bundled Payment for ESRD — Including ESAs in Medicare's Dialysis Package". N Engl J Med 364(7):593-595. [Link to PubMed]
  • Rettig RA. (2011) "Special Treatment — The Story of Medicare's ESRD Entitlement". N Engl J Med 364(7):596-598. [Link to PubMed]
  • Stanescu HC et al. (2011). "Risk HLA-DQA1 and PLA2R1 Alleles in Idiopathic Membranous Nephropathy". N Engl J Med 364(7):616-626. [Link to PubMed abstract]
  • Hemmelgarn BR et al. for the Prevention of Dialysis Catheter Lumen Occlusion with rt-PA versus Heparin (PreCLOT) Study Group. (2011). "Prevention of Dialysis Catheter Malfunction with Recombinant Tissue Plasminogen Activator". N Engl J Med 364(4):303-312. [Link to PubMed abstract]


Archives of Internal Medicine

  • Ishani A et al. (2011) "The Magnitude of Acute Serum Creatinine Increase After Cardiac Surgery and the Risk of Chronic Kidney Disease, Progression of Kidney Disease, and Death." Arch Intern Med. 2011;171(3):226-233. [Link to PubMed abstract]
  • Mehrotra R et al. (2011) "Similar Outcomes With Hemodialysis and Peritoneal Dialysis in Patients With End-Stage Renal Disease." Arch Intern Med. 2011;171(2):110-118. [Link to PubMed abstract]

The Lancet

  • Budde K et al. (2011) Everolimus-based, calcineurin-inhibitor-free regimen in recipients of de-novo kidney transplants: an open-label, randomised, controlled trial. Lancet 377(9768); 837-847. [Link to PubMed abstract]

Annals of Internal Medicine

  • Clase CM et al. (2011) "Estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate and Albuminuria as Predictors of Outcomes in Patients With High Cardiovascular Risk: A Cohort Study." 154(5):310-318. [Link to PubMed abstract]
      

 

Resources added in February 2011

 

Chronic Kidney Disease

  • Chronic Kidney Disease: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses. Updated 24 Feb 2011.
  • Kidney Care Matters - March 2011. NHS Kidney Care.
  • Anaemia management in people with chronic kidney disease. Updated NICE guideline.

  • NICE costing report on the implementation of clinical guideline for the management of anaemia in people with chronic kidney disease. National electronic Library for Medicines (10 Feb 2011).
  • Renal Tsar - NHS Evidence highlights IV Iron savings (Thu, 17 Feb 2011).
  • Renal Tsar - Q and A - How can we get individual Care Plans to become universally applied to all chronically ill patients (Fri, 04 Feb 2011).
  • Phosphate binders for preventing and treating bone disease in chronic kidney disease patients. A new Cochrane systematic review by Navaneethan Sankar D et al.
  • Renal Tsar - Paying for value not volume (Thu, 10 Feb 2011).

  • World Kidney Day 2011: Thursday 10 March 2011. Kidney Research UK.

Diabetic nephropathy

Other kidney conditions - SLE and inherited

  • Phase III study of belimumab suggests modest efficacy in active SLE. National electronic Library for Medicines (08 Feb 2011).
  • Efficacy and safety of belimumab in patients with active systemic lupus erythematosus - a randomised placebo-controlled phase 3 trial. RCT published in the Lancet by Navarra SV et al.
  • NHS Kidney Care - Supporting Young Adults with Kidney Disease.  NHS Kidney Care.
  • Genetics of Kidney Diseases: Systematic Reviews and Meta-analyses. Updated 04 March 2011.

Hypertension

  • NHS Choices assessment- New blood pressure measurement method may more accurately predict aortic systolic pressure. National electronic Library for Medicines (23 Feb 2011).
  • NICE consults on draft update to hypertension guideline.  National electronic Library for Medicines  (23 Feb 2011).
  • Home blood pressure monitoring plays a key role in hypertension management - review of applications effectiveness and technique for pharmacists. National electronic Library for Medicines (11 Feb 2011).
  • Hypertension: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses. Updated 18 Feb 2011.

Acute kidney injury

  • Renal Tsar - HSJ highlights increasing acute kidney injury costs (Wed, 09 Feb 2011).

End-Stage Renal Disease

  • End-Stage Renal Disease: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses. Updated 16 Feb 2011.
  • Prediction of ESRD and death among people with CKD - the Chronic Renal Impairment in Birmingham prospective cohort study. New cohort study published in the American Journal of Kidney Diseases by Landray MJ et al.

Renovascular diseases

  • No new resources this month.

Glomerulonephritis

  • Nephrotic syndrome: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses. Updated 18 Feb 2011.

Other renal conditions

  • No new resources this month.

Renal tract infections

  • No new resources this month.

Kidney stones

  • Mini Topic Review on Kidney Stones by Kathie Wong and Kay Thomas  - March 2011.

Renal vasculitis

Haemodialysis

Peritoneal Dialysis

  • No new resources this month.

Transplantation

  • Transmission of Multidrug-Resistant Escherichia coli Through Kidney Transplantation - California and Texas 2009. Report by Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Morbidity and Mortality Weekley - Report in JAMA.
  • ZEUS study evaluates use of everolimus-based calcineurin-inhibitor-free regimen in recipients of de-novo kidney transplants. National electronic Library for Medicines (22 Feb 2011).
  • Guidance on the microbiological safety of human organs tissues and cells used in transplantation.  Department of Health.
  • Guidelines for antibody incompatible transplantation. Updated British Transplantation Society guidance.
  • Nephrectomy: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses. Updated 18 Feb 2011.
  • Renal transplant: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses. Updated 04 March 2011.

Kidney Cancer

  • New systematic review on diabetes mellitus and the incidence of kidney cancer. NHS Evidence - cancer.
  • NICE issues guidance on pazopanib for the first-line treatment of metastatic renal cell carcinoma. National electronic Library for Medicines (24 Feb 2011).
  • Pazopanib for the first-line treatment of advanced renal cell carcinoma. NICE technology appraisal guidance.

 

Male Urogenital Disorders

  • The management of lower urinary tract symptoms in men - Commissioning Guide. NICE.

Male Ureteric Disorders

  • No new resources this month.

Male Bladder Disorders

  • New systematic reviews on bladder cancer. NHS Evidence - cancer.

Prostate Disorders

  • 2011 Annual Evidence Update on Prostate Cancer. Launched 07 March 2011. Produced by NHS Evidence - cancer and NHS Evidence - kidney diseases and male urogenital disorders.
  • Denosumab vs zoledronic acid for treatment of bone metastases in men with castration-resistant prostate cancer - RCT. National electronic Library for Medicines (01 March 2011).
  • BBC Video clip on HIFU and prostate cancer. 22 Feb 2011.

Penile Disorders

  • Erectile dysfunction: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses. Updated 21 Feb 2011

Urethral disorders

  • No new resources this month.

Urinary tract infections

  • No new resources this month.

Testicular/Scrotal Disorders

Male Urinary Incontinence

Sexually Transmitted Infections

Fertility

  • Infertility: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses. Updated 21 Feb 2011.

 

Many thanks for using and benefiting from this specialist collection for the last four-five years. The specialist collection team wish you all the best.

]]>

NHS Evidence - kidney diseases is for busy health professionals, providing them with high quality information and keeping them up to date with the latest research and developments in this area.
